[04-Feb-19 07:08 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@Mazzz network participants have a possibility to reject content they do not want to store. The more miners reject a chunk of illicit data, the smaller is the probability to find it on the weave. [20-Feb-19 03:34 AM] arweave-stan#3973
@DesignBlock just so I confirm, Arweave network do not detect duplicate files on the network....But we have a very strong policy of voluntarism on the part of the miners that creates a system for democratised content rejection -- no miner can be forced to store any content that they dislike.

Broadly, miners can maintain a lists of content (by hash and by keyword) that they will not accept in blocks - this lets them filter bad content or duplicate files without storing it themselves. The net effect of this is that even miners that don't blacklist themselves don't want to accept transactions containing content that they think will be widely rejected by other miners; if they mine these transactions into their block then there is a high likelihood that this block won't be accepted into the network, and that they will not receive their mining reward.

This system works for content that the network strongly agrees is bad, and stops it getting on to the chain in the first place, but it's obviously not possible to prevent all the content that might upset anybody being placed on the chain. However, to address this, there is also a system that allows users to post "don't serve this" transactions onto the network. These transactions post a hash of the transaction that the user doesn't want served, and lets miners make the choice about whether to serve these transactions or not.

Finally, just to specifically address any concern about your own hard drive: because the chain shards and nobody is obligated to store any content they don't wish to, if you don't like the content of a block, you can simply drop it.

{Reactions}

[15-Apr-19 04:21 AM] arweave-stan#3973
@Vilenarios regarding your question about how much storage available on the network. 

The exact data storage quantity is unknown because we use a system of incentives rather than contracts, but we recently calculated that mining would currently be profitable up to approximately 1.4 exabytes of data storage.


[15-Apr-19 04:54 AM] Mazzz#1871
@arweave-stan that's a lotta data, but it's still not infinitely scalable. What happens after 1.4 exabytes have been stored?


[15-Apr-19 05:07 AM] arweave-stan#3973
@Mazzz That is just the current maximum. By the time we get near that, it will have increased. If the storage capacity of the network has not increased, the price for adding data will increase as the limit is neared. The increase in data storage price will either cause:
A. More miners to come to the network, bringing more storage capacity, as the profitability increases.
B. Fewer people to store data, as the price increases.


[15-Apr-19 05:08 AM] arweave-stan#3973
This keeps the size of the network within reasonable bounds

[05-Mar-19 05:02 AM] ivhturp#3325
Can we delete the files once uploaded?


[05-Mar-19 05:12 AM] arweave-stan#3973
@ivhturp I don't think it would be possible to 'delete' files as the underlying structure of the weave is truly designed for absolute permanence..


[05-Mar-19 06:19 AM] ivhturp#3325
If anyone uploads a file by mistake, is it not possible to undo it   This feature may be required for general users AFAIK


[05-Mar-19 06:26 AM] tiamat#9131
@ivhturp can you undo if you send 100 ETH to someone by mistake?


[05-Mar-19 06:28 AM] arweave-stan#3973
@ivhturp This is certainly something I've as well thought about, but it wouldn't be possible to 'undo' files as I already said the underlying structure of the weave is truly designed for absolute permanence, and 'undoing' would require deleting the  previous file version which is not possible. However, there could perhaps be an app built ontop of the blockweave that handles uploading only the differences between the existing document and the updated document, which would cost less AR than uploading a brand new document. But this isn't something we currently have in our plans at the moment as a team. Community developers are very welcome though, and we'll help people out with developing on the weave as much as possible!

[17-Apr-19 04:00 AM] Marcin#0065
Is there an app which is able to convert big files into pieces and then upload it in the weave and provides you will all needed links to gather all pieces together back again?


[17-Apr-19 04:31 AM] arweave-stan#3973
@Marcin I don't have information on how much the whole wikileaks is at the moment, but if you know the size, you can check how much it will cost to store it on the Arweave.  There is a HTTP endpoint giving estimations: /price/<size-in-bytes>. It responds with a price in Winston so divide by 1000000000000.


[17-Apr-19 05:21 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@Marcin we have a prototype that can take your file, and upload it in chunks. Then it can take  a TX ID and recollect the chunks back into a file. Unfortunately, there are a couple of known issues making it not very easy to use (it does not properly account for forks so it may upload with holes and it does not tell you when the upload is finished so you should check logs every once in a while to pick TX IDs and see if it downloads the original file back).

Some external contributions would be very welcome in this area. https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/issues/138 https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/issues/139

 
https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/issues/138

https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/issues/139

[31-Jan-19 09:09 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We have said what we can: namely that we are in the process of exchange integration. We recently (Tuesday) also released a mining client upgrade that makes it easier for people to integrate with Arweave.


[31-Jan-19 09:10 AM] arweave-sam#9630
I also explained in a recent email (last week?) why integration with Arweave is more complex than other tokens


[31-Jan-19 09:11 AM] arweave-sam#9630
ERC-20s are literally a couple of lines to integrate, then most 'main net' tokens are forked from each other to some extent or another, so they share a common API. We are one of very few tokens that are truly written from scratch.


[31-Jan-19 09:12 AM] Rabbi#2072
Viewblock and Upvest integrated your token just fine


[31-Jan-19 09:12 AM] Rabbi#2072
Any competent exchange can do the same


[31-Jan-19 09:12 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We recently did an analysis of some exchanges that list hundreds of token pairs. We worked out that there were perhaps ~15 truly unique interfaces for these tokens.


[31-Jan-19 09:13 AM] arweave-sam#9630
> Viewblock and Upvest integrated your token just fine

VB only read data from the weave, so that is super simple. We were working with Upvest for many months before launch of the network.


[31-Jan-19 09:15 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Before we were 'discovered' by the wider crypto community shortly after the private sale ended, we had been working with a decentralised exchange that we planned to list on just after launch. Unfortunately, after the massive influx of new community members we had it quickly became clear that this dex wasn't going to be able to handle the traffic appropriately.


[31-Jan-19 09:15 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Subsequently, we found more appropriate exchange partners and began to work with them.


[31-Jan-19 09:17 AM] arweave-sam#9630
> dont break the NDA

You might be surprised how difficult this is. Good exchanges move markets, so the best ones required projects not to release *any* details until the listing is complete in order to avoid potential market shenanigans. This is good for the long-term (shows they are serious about compliance and fairness for their customers), but it makes things difficult prior to the listing.

[10-Mar-19 09:24 PM] DesignBlock#0184
@arweave-stan why is that? Isnt it storing a single file with large size much cheaper than storing many files of same total size?


[10-Mar-19 09:25 PM] DesignBlock#0184
@arweave-stan how pricing works? Will they connect it to coinmarketcap price or something?


[10-Mar-19 09:27 PM] DesignBlock#0184
@arweave-lev so price is related with storage demand, not AR price


[11-Mar-19 05:03 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@DesignBlock It's cheaper to split one large files into several small transactions compared to upload the whole file in one large transaction. 1MB is a reasonable chunk-size when splitting. It's easier for the network to handle many small transactions. Therefore the price incentivises the users to split up their large files into smaller transactions.

{Reactions}
  

[11-Mar-19 05:05 AM] arweave-stan#3973
 


[11-Mar-19 09:55 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@DesignBlock the price in AR is initially based on an estimation of the storage costs in fiat and the ICO price of AR, but it is adjusted according to the network difficulty. Our team is working on the paper, which would explain the economic model behind the price in detail.

[19-Feb-18 12:49 AM] BBM#0001
Since the concept behind Archain is an uncensorable internet, is there any notion of removing something from the blockweave? I was wondering if any considerations had been made with regards to the legalities around storing/mining the data if someone has chosen to store things that most people would not want, i.e. child pornography. If I were to be holder of that data and it be considered rare data, would I not be held responsible for distribution of that - perhaps without my knowledge?


[20-Feb-18 06:12 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
@vyrrt

Though it is not widely discussed in our whitepaper, we have a very strong policy of voluntarism on the part of the miners that creates a system for democratised content rejection -- no miner can be forced to store any content that they dislike.

Broadly, miners can maintain a lists of content (by hash and by keyword) that they will not accept in blocks - this lets them filter bad content without storing it themselves. The net effect of this is that even miners that don't blacklist themselves don't want to accept transactions containing content that they think will be widely rejected by other miners; if they mine these transactions into their block then there is a high likelihood that this block won't be accepted into the network, and that they will not receive their mining reward.

This system works for content that the network strongly agrees is bad, and stops it getting on to the chain in the first place, but it's obviously not possible to prevent all the content that might upset anybody being placed on the chain. However, to address this, there is also a system that allows users to post "don't serve this" transactions onto the network. These transactions post a hash of the transaction that the user doesn't want served, and lets miners make the choice about whether to serve these transactions or not.

Finally, just to specifically address any concern about your own hard drive: because the chain shards and nobody is obligated to store any content they don't wish to, if you don't like the content of a block, you can simply drop it.

[11-May-18 08:39 AM] WillRogerJones#8527

[11-May-18 08:39 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
One second though, I might be able to give you a command so you don't have to reset the server


[11-May-18 08:52 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Okay, if you add a new line below -module(ar_join). in ar_join.erl


[11-May-18 08:52 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
-export([fill_to_capacity/3]).


[11-May-18 08:53 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
you should then be able to run the command:


[11-May-18 08:53 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
ar_join:fill_to_capacity(ar_bridge:get_remote_peers(whereis(http_bridge_node)), whereis(http_entrypoint_node)).


[11-May-18 08:53 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
from the server


[11-May-18 08:53 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
this should resume the fast block collecting behavior

[02-Jul-18 07:40 AM] arweave-kyle#4569

I am guessing that I can’t access the archive link from second device, maybe I am wrong. Haven’t tried yet


[02-Jul-18 09:10 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Ahhhh, okay. So all data is currently stored locally, so multiple devices aren't supported. We're looking at changing this and moving to pulling all data from the network, so this will be supported in future though, and the scenario you described where your PC crashes and you need to reinstall it should also be resolved by this too


[02-Jul-18 09:11 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Anyone can use the archive links though. So if you grab the URL from the transactions page, anyone can view that data if you send them the link, they don't need the extension or anything, just the URL.

[19-Jul-18 04:34 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Regarding resource limits, are you interested in disk space or CPU limiting?


[19-Jul-18 07:09 AM] Căpitanu#5971

[19-Jul-18 07:11 AM] Căpitanu#5971

[19-Jul-18 11:13 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
@Căpitanu there's a `disk_space` argument you can pass when you start your node, just add the max amount of GB you want to use e.g. `disk_space 10` if you wanted to use a max of 10GB. So in context the full startup command would look something like `./arweave-server mine peer xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx disk_space 10`.


[19-Jul-18 11:14 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Regarding CPU the software will currently use the number of cores on your machine - 1, so on a 4 (logical) core machine the software will try to use up 3 of those cores, so you'll see something close to 100% usage on a typical node when you're mining. This is something we'll likely add as a configurable value in future releases, similar to how the max disk space is configurable


[19-Jul-18 11:16 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
On your node @Căpitanu , does the log show that you're mining any blocks yet? Keep in mind your node will need to have pulled enough blocks so that you've gone some of the recall blocks, if you don't have the current recall block your node won't be able to participate in mining the next block

[20-Jul-18 04:39 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
@Căpitanu that's normal, your node will continually be writing blocks to disk until it's downloaded as many as it can, if you started in the last few days the block height was about 20k so until that initial batch have been downloaded you'll see this continual writing of blocks in the background


[20-Jul-18 04:39 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
More blocks (potential recall blocks) means you're able to participate in mining more future blocks, so you should see more mining activity as you store more and more of the weave

[02-Oct-18 09:21 AM] tiamat#9131
what is hash_lists directory?


[02-Oct-18 07:11 PM] arweave-sam#9630
The hash lists directory contains dumps of lists of the independent hashes of every block in the network. One for each execution of the Arweave miner. They are mostly there for safely purposes and can be safely deleted by individual miners, as you download the block hash list from trusted peers each time you join the net anyway.

[05-Oct-18 02:39 PM] arweave-sam#9630
(For those interested: There was a change to how the LB host detected whether a node was 'up', which led to it misinterpreting the ~7 nodes behind the balancer as 'down'. This change wasn't made clear to us so it took a while to identify the cause of the issue. Thanks for your patience, all!)

[16-Oct-18 02:03 PM] Mimi#1207

[16-Oct-18 02:03 PM] arweave-india#5075
Let me copy & paste the instructions for you @Mimi


[16-Oct-18 02:03 PM] arweave-india#5075
1. Install the Arweave web extension from the Google Chrome Web Store: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US 

2. Right-click the extension icon (the Arweave logo) on your browser and go to ‘Options’, this brings up the Arweave wallet interface

3. Go to ‘Wallet Options’ in the bottom left and select ‘Generate Wallet’

4. Download the key file, storing it somewhere you will remember, and naming it something memorable

5. Go to ‘Wallet Options’ again, click ‘Load Wallet’

6. Drag and drop the key file into the box provided

7. Set a password for your wallet (optional but recommended)

 
https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US
Arweave client
The Arweave project web extension.
https://images-ext-2.discordapp.net/external/CgNIvrKWS-VP9BsiNw_lkTocSQdYrDEt1_Ark87Bz30/https/lh3.googleusercontent.com/DkeqjE6hm0k0bxkk5VdmAOO5gLvuVfkXgt2KNmbQ1VjLTbpK6vfFV2t2CVcLb1gamyO1d8ZrIg%3Dw128-h128-e365

[02-Nov-18 08:52 AM] kevint#5113

[02-Nov-18 08:54 AM] kevint#5113
kevin@DESKTOP-3FQ7NJJ:~$ curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/stable/install.sh
#!/bin/bash
echo "-----INSTALLING DEPENDENCIES-----"
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y gcc make build-essential autoconf m4 libncurses5-dev libssh-dev unixodbc-dev openjdk-8-jdk libwxgtk3.0-dev xsltproc fop
wget http://www.erlang.org/download/otp_src_20.1.tar.gz
tar -zvxf otp_src_20.1.tar.gz
cd otp_src_20.1
export ERL_TOP=`pwd`
echo "-----BUILDING ERLANG-----"
./configure --without-wx
make -j4
sudo make install
echo "-----INSTALLED ERLANG SUCCESFULLY-----"
cd ../
sudo apt-get install -y git
echo "-----CLONING ARWEAVE REPO-----"
git clone https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave.git arweave && cd arweave && git -c advice.detachedHead=false checkout stable
make all
echo "-----FINISHED INSTALLATION-----"


[02-Nov-18 08:56 AM] Mike#2447

Hey @KeeJef , currently the gateways are just load balancers with some request mapping

[11-Feb-19 03:58 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
At the moment they're off the shelf load balancers so we don't have any specific code to give out. We're working on our own replacement for this though with more features.

You could setup something as simple as a digital ocean load balancer if you want something quick and easy for now https://www.digitalocean.com/products/load-balancer/, or you could setup your own using nginx http://nginx.org/en/docs/http/load_balancing.html which will give you more control


[11-Feb-19 03:58 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
That way you can have my-arweave-nodes.org accept requests and send them to your miners to serve content from


[12-Feb-19 02:06 AM] KeeJef#7523
Sorry i forgot to respond to this, so how does this actually work. when a request is made to the gateway does it have to communicate directly with a miner? how is the load balancing done currently for your gateway, is there some command in the arweave daemon (i assume this is a thing) i can call to get a list of all miners on the network? or do you guys just have a list of hardcoded miners that you fetch data from?


[12-Feb-19 03:58 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
There's nothing specific to arweave going on with load balancers at the moment. When you configure a load balancer you just tell it what to listen for and where to send the request, so ours listen for requests on port 80 and 443 (http and https ports), and then it forwards the requests to a set of arweave nodes.


[12-Feb-19 03:58 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
The load balancer also takes care of checking to see if the nodes are responding slowly/down etc and then routes traffic around them.


[12-Feb-19 03:59 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
As I said though these are features of a standard off the shelf  load balancers, not arweve specific at the moment

[25-Feb-19 08:00 PM] KeeJef#7523
whats actually happening inbetween the raw and the rendered


[26-Feb-19 03:42 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Hey @KeeJef , the raw transactions you see on /tx/{hash} are just JSON objects, the data is base64 encoded


[26-Feb-19 03:44 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
When you request the transaction hash without the /tx/ part the node just extracts the data field and base64 decodes the response for you. When sending a transaction you can add a  content type tag and this will control the content type http header the node puts on the response, so tagging a  transaction with 'Content-Type: text/html' makes sure it gets server correctly as a html page


[26-Feb-19 03:48 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
The same works for PDFs for example, you can base64 encode the pdf and put it in the data field of a transaction, then add a 'Content-Type: application/pdf' tag and the nodes will serve the PDF to browsers correctly (e.g. http://arweave.net/MQy6AXiqZGmHcrMMlNuH6m_tBMYymoAx1jcXI51_ouM)


[26-Feb-19 03:49 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
you can see the base64 decoded tags for that pdf example here https://viewblock.io/arweave/tx/MQy6AXiqZGmHcrMMlNuH6m_tBMYymoAx1jcXI51_ouM


[26-Feb-19 09:49 PM] KeeJef#7523
Sweet, think ive got it worked out

[07-Apr-19 06:12 AM] njm#6915
Hi Guys. I'm looking to setup an Arweave wallet on an airgapped PC. For transactions, I want to have the ability to sign Arweave transactions on the airgapped machine, & then broadcast on the online machine. Is this possible?


[07-Apr-19 05:42 PM] njm#6915
Pinging @arweave-india  @arweave-martin


[08-Apr-19 03:21 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey @njm ! Yes, that is definitely possible


[08-Apr-19 03:22 AM] arweave-sam#9630
You would need to find a way of securely setting up the signing software on the air gapped machine, then also find a way of securely moving signed transactions between the machines.


[08-Apr-19 03:23 AM] arweave-sam#9630
I don't think that the `arweave deploy` tool currently has an option for 'export signed tx, but don't broadcast', but I will check with @arweave-kyle


[08-Apr-19 03:30 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Hey @njm, is it data transactions or wallet to wallet transactions you’re looking to sign on your airgapped machine?


[08-Apr-19 03:48 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@njm your air-gapped machine can peer with an online machine so that transactions added to the air-gapped machine are posted to the online one (off course, you need set up networking so that this is the only machine that can talk to the air-gapped one).  To sign transactions on the air-gapped machine, this API can help - https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/master/http_post_unsigned_tx_docs.md.


[08-Apr-19 07:16 AM] Lasse Clausen#6198
@arweave-martin any ideas about this? has anyone ever got it setup so that tweets are automatically added to the Arweave?


[08-Apr-19 07:16 AM] Lasse Clausen#6198
https://www.dropbox.com/s/r3rceypmq5ldu60/Photo%2006.04.19%2C%2014%2058%2034.png?dl=0


[10-Apr-19 03:49 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@Lasse Clausen I'm suspecting this is what happens if you're creating a transaction before your last one was mined. Does it sound reasonable that this is what happened to you? Currently, you can only have one transaction per wallet per block.


[10-Apr-19 03:53 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Yes, the multi-tx per wallet per block patch is waiting for the next hard fork. At the moment the first TX will clobber the second (removing it from the mempool) as the `GET /wallet/____/last_tx` endpoint returns the last _mined_ transaction ID, not the last seen TXID. Currently it is up to the client in question to keep track of the last_tx's if it wants to chain them.


[10-Apr-19 04:18 AM] rehash#3438
is there an aprox date/timeframe for the next hard fork?


[10-Apr-19 04:36 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Currently we are looking at having it ready in the next 6 weeks or so, but we will firm up the dates once we have a 'feature freeze' on exactly what will be making it into this version.


[10-Apr-19 04:37 AM] arweave-sam#9630
The process will be basically the same as the last one: We will let you know the feature list, patch nodes, and release the final build approximately a week before the hard fork will trigger.


[10-Apr-19 04:38 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We will then put notifications in the # tech-announcements channel here, as well as on our twitter and on the mining mailing list.

[15-Apr-19 04:25 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Sure! You would have to rearrange the JSON output from the debug screen so that it represents a 'flat' transaction (move the nested JSON dict properties into the upper context), then `POST /tx` this to the network. The easiest way to do probably with curl, if you are comfortable with using the command line.

[29-Apr-19 03:43 AM] Daxter#3955
Hi, sorry for the super basic question, but do I have to spend tokens every time I want to update my permaweb page? Is it even possible to do so(as in keeping the same address, I get that the old page is there forever)? Or is the idea to complete something without deploying it, then deploy the page exactly once at the end?


[29-Apr-19 04:15 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Hey @Daxter uploads are fundamentally immutable, the IDs which go into the URL are derived from the transaction signature, which in turn is derived from the transaction data, previous transaction id, network fee, etc. So if you wanted to update an uploaded page you would simply upload a new version with a new ID and the old page would remain there still.


[29-Apr-19 04:16 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Depending on the use case it might be possible for a client to implement diffs, and then just upload diffs and have the client piece the current version together a bit like git, however if it's a webpage simply uploading a new version with a new ID and url is the way to go as browsers aren't that smart


[29-Apr-19 04:25 AM] Daxter#3955
Thanks  


[29-Apr-19 12:33 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Yep -- you can then just update your DNS (etc.) records to point to the TXID of the new version, but everyone that has a copy of the old ID will still be able to access the old version  


[09-May-19 06:20 PM] Zeus#2212
What I would suggest Daxter is to have a request to a server where it has some details of your project, including the version. And each page you deploy (update) will have a newer version. If the person visit the old page then they will get a small alert saying to go to the new address (pointing to the new page ID that you set in your server details)


[10-May-19 04:35 AM] arweave-lev#3466
I think there is a way to do it without leaving the borders of the Permaweb - make the app query transactions from the same wallet with the application tag. Another tag could be introduced to be able to give "permissions" to a different wallet.


[10-May-19 09:08 AM] Zeus#2212

[26-Jun-18 09:16 AM] arweave-india#5075
   Arweave tokens are now transferable, meaning they can be sent to and from wallets on the Arweave network.    

The Arweave web extension has also now been published, and offers the dual functionality of a basic native Arweave wallet, and the ability to use your AR tokens to archive webpages. This signifies the completion of our very first use case on the Arweave mainnet - permanently archiving web pages! 

Here is the link to download the Arweave extension from the Chrome Web Store: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US. Once you have installed the extension, right-click on the icon and select ‘Options’ to get started.

Please note that for  the Upvest wallet, users may need to clear their cache and cookies in order to see the ‘send’ button.  You can continue to use the Upvest wallet if you choose.

The Arweave wallet can also be used as a cold wallet. If you would like these instructions please email the team at team@arweave.org requesting these instructions.

 
https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US.
Arweave client
The Arweave project web extension.

[26-Jun-18 09:18 AM] arweave-india#5075
Instructions for creating your Arweave wallet:

1. Install the Arweave web extension from the Google Chrome Web Store: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US 

2. Right-click the extension icon (the Arweave logo) on your browser and go to ‘Options’, this brings up the Arweave wallet interface

3. Go to ‘Wallet Options’ in the bottom left and select ‘Generate Wallet’

4. Download the key file, storing it somewhere you will remember, and naming it something memorable

5. Go to ‘Wallet Options’ again, click ‘Load Wallet’

6. Drag and drop the key file into the box provided

7. Set a password for your wallet (optional but recommended) - please type this very carefully. You are responsible for remembering your password and recording it accurately, Arweave cannot recover your wallet if you lose your password.

 
https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US
Arweave client
The Arweave project web extension.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/gybvxzb5tIwhtDEy9mVotTUO8ef5jkDp9h9m2ledABU/https/lh3.googleusercontent.com/QEmIvhOjpBbXc7VLEDlC0YFlQzabOT2NuaogLuEdg2OQdH3hL2bWNnkXK2lxlGrZtBiSUoyqpYE%3Dw128-h128-e365


[27-Jun-18 01:22 PM] arweave-india#5075
Remember:

- Arweave tokens are not ERC-20 tokens, so cannot be used with Ethereum network wallets. AR tokens are native tokens to the Arweave network.

- If you send tokens to an address that does not exist on the Arweave network, you will not be able to recover your tokens. So, do not ever send your AR tokens to an Ethereum wallet address.

- We strongly recommend performing a test transaction with a small quantity of AR tokens, especially when sending to a new address or when using the Arweave or Upvest wallets for the first time.

[05-Sep-18 04:24 AM] arweave-india#5075
Hi all,

Here is a mini-update of what we have been up to:

- Arweave version 1.5 is nearing release. This version builds considerably on the initial main network release, changing approximately 20% of the codebase and delivering faster data access and a more reliable mining experience. This has been the focus on our dev team’s work for a while now, so we’re really excited to get this shipped soon. 

- The second version of the Arweave web extension, with significantly improved user experience (thanks to your community feedback!) is also nearer release. Among the user interface changes, this update will also add features like multiple wallet support.

- Progress continues on the ArchiveIt! permanent file backup system, improving its user interface and general ease of use.

- Exciting work continues bringing new businesses and customers to the network — we will release names at an appropriate moment  .

- We have hired 3 new members of staff, and are in the process of filling three further positions.

- Less exciting, but still necessary operations update: we now have a new office that will be able to accommodate our growing team!

Regarding exchanges: I am sure that you all understand the situation by now - we are in high level talks with a number of exchanges, and we are continuing to make progress, though we cannot discuss any further details publicly at this stage. We would love to tell you all about our progress, but doing so would put that progress itself in jeopardy. We thank you sincerely for your understanding.

[29-Jan-19 09:55 AM] arweave-martin#1169
Today we're happy to announce the release of 1.6.1.0 of the Arweave Node. This includes a lot of changes since the last release 1.6.1.0 in late November. Here is the digest:

* Rewrite/remake of the custom port feature. When all nodes have upgraded, you will be able to run the miner on other ports than 1984.
* Less verbose output when starting `arweave-server`.
* Added transaction status endpoint (/tx/[transaction_id]/status). See http_iface_docs.md
* Added endpoint for listing all transactions for an wallet (/wallet/[wallet_address]/txs/[earliest_tx]). See http_iface_docs.md
* Let the node create wallets and sign transactions for you. See http_post_unsigned_tx_docs.md
* Mixed improvements to make the node run more reliably.
* Faster block propagation.

Upgrade instructions:
1. Shut down arweave-server.
2. `git fetch --all --tags && git checkout master && git reset --hard N.1.6.1.0`
3. Start arweave-server again with the same arguments as before.

If you're looking for peers to start arweave-server with, you are welcome to use the recently updated peer list found in the mining guide. These peers are all operated by the Arweave organization. https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide

 
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide
https://images-ext-2.discordapp.net/external/G8HLYFWMprhy7yK2e31zT0zItU5ekMF6HVGvcVWZzM4/https/www.gitbook.com/share/space/thumbnail/-LRMphNRIDGSg4iSR6kj.png

[06-Mar-19 10:03 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@here Today we are happy to announce the release 1.6.2.0 of the Arweave Node!

We have
- Significantly increased the efficiency of block and transaction propagation.
- Sped up the fork recovery process.
- Added a `GET /wallet/[Addr]/deposits` endpoint for fetching incoming transfers for a wallet. For more details, see https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/N.1.6.2.0/http_iface_docs.md.
- Fixed a bug in the `POST /unsigned_tx` endpoint where it required irrelevant data. The updated endpoint documentation is at https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/N.1.6.2.0/http_post_unsigned_tx_docs.md.
- Made various reliability improvements.

Upgrade instructions:

1. Shut down `arweave-server`.
2. `git fetch --all --tags && git checkout master && git reset --hard N.1.6.2.0`
3. Start `arweave-server` again with the same arguments as before.

For more details on how to run the node, please see our mining guide -
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide.

Pay attention to the recommended list of peers. It has not been updated since the last release. These peers are all operated by the Arweave organization.

And a little bonus for those willing to contribute - we have prepared a simple guide for external contributors - https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md, check it out!

[04-Apr-19 05:23 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@here Today we are happy to announce the release 1.6.3 of the Arweave Node!

In it:

1. The `block/hash/[hash]` and `block/height/[height]` HTTP endpoints do not return a hash list by default anymore. Viewing blocks in a browser/other HTTP client is now much faster!
2. Reliability improvements of the time measurement for difficulty adjustments.
3. Various reliability improvements for the mining worker processes.
4. New mining benchmark tool, using real candidate block production to measure mining performance much more accurately. You can run it with `./arweave-server benchmark`.Note: As the new benchmarking tool tests real block production speed, not just pure hashing power, it may appear that the effective hashing rate has decreased. This is false. As it happens, the changes mentioned in point 3 lead to improved mining performance.

Upgrade instructions:

1. Shut down arweave-server. To make sure the shutdown was successful, run `ps aux | grep beam`. The output should only have a single line with `grep beam` at the end.
2. git fetch --all --tags && git checkout master && git reset --hard N.1.6.3.1
3. Start arweave-server again with the same arguments as before.

For more details on how to run the node, please see our mining guide -                                                 
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide.

Pay attention to the recommended list of peers. It has not been updated since the last release. These peers are all operated by the Arweave organization, so use them if you trust them - alternatively join on the IP address of another trusted node.


[04-Apr-19 09:28 AM] arweave-lev#3466
If any of you has already updated to N.1.6.3.0, consider updating to N.1.6.3.1. I've also updated the release announcement above to mention N.16.3.1. Under "/info" you should see `"release:" 23`.

At this point I would guess that 4 TB is probably a safe start.  Again, hopefully the dev team can chime in with more specific information.  As for getting started, are you able to install Linux on your mining computer?  That's the first step.

[29-Jun-18 07:21 AM] Mike#2447
After you get your Debian/Ubuntu installation all set and up to date, you can  open a terminal and run the following commands one line at a time.  I changed the Erlang version from 20.1 in the original instructions to the newer 20.3 release.  Version 21.0 is out, but I don't know if there are compatibility issues or not.

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y gcc make build-essential autoconf m4 libncurses5-dev libssh-dev unixodbc-dev openjdk-8-jdk libwxgtk3.0-dev xsltproc fop
wget http://www.erlang.org/download/otp_src_20.3.tar.gz
tar -zvxf otp_src_20.3.tar.gz
cd otp_src_20.3
export ERL_TOP=`pwd`
./configure
make
sudo make install
cd ../
sudo apt-get install -y git
git clone https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave.git

After cloning the repo, enter the  following commands to test your setup.  If everything completes with "OK", you should be ready to mine.

cd arweave
make all tnt

Once the peer IP list is released to the public you can mine with the following command.
./arweave-server mine peer XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX

Or you can run with the polling flag if you have issues with forwarding port 1984.
./arweave-server mine polling peer XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX

I'm fairly certain this information is all correct, but if a member of the dev team wants to jump in and comment it would be appreciated.

[06-Jul-18 12:16 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Hi @Mike, it is best to use port forwarding, rather than polling, as it is substantially more efficient. You just need port 1984 to forward to your machine on your local network -- this can usually be configured by your router.

Reports like these are always helpful, but probably best to send them directly to @arweave-india who can collective the details and add issues directly to our internal tracking system.

[15-Jul-18 04:25 AM] codybartfast#9308
Well done to the team on the greatly improved mining software. Thank you.  

I have it running on WSL (Unbuntu 16.04), on Windows 10, on a home network, behind a consumer wireless router.  I'd just like share a few things from my experience...


[15-Jul-18 04:25 AM] codybartfast#9308
.

## Getting the Latest Erlang on WSL Ubuntu

apt-get seemed to only install Erlang 18, this site: https://hostpresto.com/community/tutorials/how-to-install-erlang-on-ubuntu-16-04/ has instructions for getting the latest version of Erlang.  The main commands are:

wget https://packages.erlang-solutions.com/erlang-solutions_1.0_all.deb 

sudo dpkg -i erlang-solutions_1.0_all.deb

sudo apt-get update

sudo apt-get install erlang

I then received Erlang 21


[15-Jul-18 04:26 AM] codybartfast#9308
.

## Opening the Windows Firewall port.

Once the mining node is running I needed to open the port in the Windows Firewall.

First I checked it was accessible locally with http://127.0.0.1:1984/info

These are some generic instructions for allowing an inbound connection: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/identity-protection/windows-firewall/create-an-inbound-port-rule

The options I chose used were:

    type: port

    protocol: tcp
    specific local port: 1984

    Action:  Allow the Connection

    Profile: All

    Name: Arweave

Once the firewall was open I could access the node from another machine on the network using its private address:  e.g., http://192.168.abc.xyz:1984/info


[15-Jul-18 04:26 AM] codybartfast#9308
.

## Port Forwarding

On my wifi router I first created a DHCP lease reservation (giving the node a fixed IP address) then I could create a Port forwarding rule from 1984 (external port) to 1984 (internal port) with the fixed ip address of the node.  How this is done is very different for every router manufacturer.

To test it I googled "What's my IP" from my home network to get my public IP Address.  Then from my phone, using the mobile network (i.e., with Wi-Fi disabled), I checked I had access to http://a.b.c.d:1984/info where a.b.c.d is my public IP address.

Once that worked the node was able to join the weave.

[16-Jul-18 04:38 AM] arthur#6010
Is there a benefit of using an SSD instead of HDD for storage?


[16-Jul-18 06:05 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Hey @Amy, sorry not sure I understand your question , is it in relation to soft onboarding for mining?


[16-Jul-18 06:07 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
@tadaams it's not something we've tested, but our recommended OS is ubuntu 18.04 and that supports ARM architectures so it might be possible


[16-Jul-18 06:08 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
It's not something we specifically support but it looks like it might work, assuming everything compiles correctly


[16-Jul-18 06:09 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
We can look into it in future, but if you have some hardware and you try it do let us know how you get on


[16-Jul-18 06:13 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
@arthur Currently there's not really a notable benefit to SSDs over HDDs in the system, nodes rank each other based on speed of access over the network which will almost always be a bigger bottleneck than HDD vs SDD access speed. Currently blocks and transactions are stored in individual files on your machine but if this changes in future to a different storage format with compression etc then it might possibly make more of a difference then, but this is speculation at the moment

[16-Jul-18 07:27 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey Sunny, Marcin, ak1, we added an artificial delay to the process of downloading old blocks for the opening phase. This is temporary and will be removed very soon. We did this because we wanted to (and have) avoided a situation where hundreds/thousands of new miners request the ~20gb of the Arweave already generated at exactly the same moment, from a comparatively low number of peers.

[17-Jul-18 03:28 AM] mickey#7342
i got a couple of noob questions

1) let say if network internet speed and hard disk drive are constant and the CPU is a variable
   - A mining rig has 4 cores and 1 core hashrate is 2.5mh/s while B mining rig has 8 cores with same hashrate 2.5mh/s
   - A mining rig can mine 1 AR per day, is it B mining rig will be at least double, mine 2.33 AR per day ??? 
    ( 1 AR x 7 x 2.5mh/s ) / ( 3 x 2.5mh/s) = 2.33 AR 

2) let say if network internet speed and CPU are constant and hard disk drive is a variable
   - A mining rig has 10TB while B mining rig has 20TB
   - A mining rig can mine 1 AR per day, will B mining rig mine double , 2 AR per day ???


[17-Jul-18 04:41 AM] Omeed - Blocktech Studios#2608
Hello, is there any tangible benefit to exceeding the 8gb of RAM recommendations as a minimum?


[17-Jul-18 06:01 AM] arthur#6010
I've only been running for a day but ram usage is 1.3GB


[17-Jul-18 06:02 AM] Vilenarios#8742
I have 32GB of ram but only been mining for a day. Will share my numbers once available. I don’t expect to see any benefit but will be good info.


[17-Jul-18 08:01 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
@mickey 

1) yeah as you've correctly pointed out it's 3 mining cores vs 7. Currently the node will mine on the number of logical cores - 1, so 3 vs 7 not 4 vs 8.

2) You don't earn AR directly based on the amount of free storage, it's an indirect relationship. You're incentivised to store as much of the weave as is possible so you have the recall block as often as possible, as recall blocks are required to mine a block. Today 10TB vs 20TB isn't going to make much of a difference as they're both much larger than the total weave size currently, however in 12 months time this might change and if you're not able to store any more blocks due to low disk space then you're less likely to have the recall blocks required, so less likely to be able to participate in mining, so less likely to make as much AR per day as a node with a larger disk.


[17-Jul-18 08:58 AM] Omeed - Blocktech Studios#2608
@Vilenarios @arthur thanks!

[18-Jul-18 12:32 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Your CPU usage will be low until you have the recall block required to mine the next block in the system. As you progressively download more blocks from the network, your CPU usage overtime will increase.


[18-Jul-18 12:33 PM] arweave-sam#9630
If you decide to store all of the blocks, your CPU utilisation should eventually be at 100% of all bar one core.

[20-Jul-18 12:39 AM] arweave-sam#9630

[20-Jul-18 12:39 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We don't use ANNs in Arweave


[20-Jul-18 12:39 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We wondered for a while if we could add a simulator into the consensus mechanism


[20-Jul-18 12:39 AM] arweave-sam#9630
But ANNs don't really have the right properties


[20-Jul-18 12:40 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We have spoken about what would happen if you trained a convulutional neural network on the Arweave in, say, 10 years


[20-Jul-18 12:40 AM] arweave-sam#9630
But we didn't get far with the idea


[20-Jul-18 12:41 AM] arweave-sam#9630
On further studying the ANN-as-PoW thing, too, it seems very dangerous.


[20-Jul-18 12:42 AM] arweave-sam#9630
You don't really want to create decentralised economic incentives for humans to always run an AI.


[20-Jul-18 12:42 AM] arweave-sam#9630
If it reached a point of generalised intelligence, that could be disastrous.


[20-Jul-18 12:43 AM] arweave-sam#9630
You want these things to be easy to turn off, not for people to be selfishly motivated in a decentralised fashion to keep them on.

[30-Jul-18 09:54 AM] Mike#2447
In order to mine arweave, you need to possess the recall block that is randomly selected each round.  If you've only downloaded the last 50 blocks, then the chance of the next recall block being one of those 50 is slim and getting slimmer, as there are currently over 34,000 blocks.  The incentive to hold all the blocks is so that you will be able to actively mine every round.

[02-Aug-18 01:14 AM] codybartfast#9308
Irrc, the slow frequency of block download is intentional  at the moment and could be increased later.  Currently there are a relatively large number of new mines compared to the number of mines with a complete block history, if all the new mines downloaded at the maximum rate then it might create an heavy load for the established mines.   (So I guess that once the number of new mines is a smaller proportion of the total number of mines then it could be increased).

[03-Aug-18 12:50 AM] codybartfast#9308
@Joel That's a normal message and shows things are working well.  When a new block is being mined you need to a have the recall block (an older existing block selected  when the previous block was mined) if you have that existing block you'll get a "started_miner:" message (and CPU usage will be high), if you don't have the recall block you'll get that message and the CPU can cool down until the next block is mined.   Over time the you should see fewer of could_not_start_mining messages.


[03-Aug-18 01:32 AM] codybartfast#9308
@Marcin I can't speak for the team, and I don't pretend to fully understand the principles behind arweave, but if were in their shoes I’d be looking for solutions that used the weave rather than creating a side channel.   I’m not sure to what extent the Wildfire protocol does, or will, play into this: “The higher the rank of a peer the faster a node will send it data in the future”.  It seems the easiest (though not the fastest) way to have a near complete block chain when mining rewards become available is to just leave the miner running, that helps build up the network.  Having said that, it is frustratingly slow - like watching Achilles and the tortoise.

[03-Aug-18 02:17 PM] Joel#5880
Solved it: This is what you need to do:

In Windows Explorer, first copy the 'prometheus_process_collector.so' file from "D:\arweave\lib\prometheus_process_collector\priv"
Then in Windows Explorer, delete the 'priv' file located at: "D:\arweave\lib\prometheus_process_collector_build\default\lib\prometheus_process_collector".
Now create a folder called 'priv' and paste the file that you copied earlier inside that folder.

You're welcome!

[04-Aug-18 01:00 AM] codybartfast#9308
I _think_ there are two ways the mine gets new blocks.  While it's running you should always receive newly mined blocks as they're sent out for verification and the recall block get's distributed with it.  The  writing_block_to_disk blocks are then needed to fill in the gaps before the mine was started.

[04-Aug-18 01:08 AM] codybartfast#9308
I mine a few blocks a day, but I'm expecting that to drop to near zero once there is real money at stake and 'serious' miners get involved     I have a console open and leave "make log | grep reward_address" running to see who's winning and yes, it's > 90% to the same address.   If you mine a block it's easy to spot because the log will show your address in base64 (e.g.  bPzNKfH0NVkJVahBQ8O2ugqaZW7-DOpt1JxrDFHD-7c) instead of numeric digits.

[04-Aug-18 03:22 AM] codybartfast#9308
Hi @S A L M O N  it should work with low CPU but the chances of mining new blocks seems very roughly to be the product of the how much of the block you store and the amount of CPU  (apparently GPU isn't relevant),   I.e. half the cpu power would half the chances.  Currently bandwidth demands seem low.

[09-Aug-18 06:39 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Hey @codybartfast, @Mike yeah you're correct about the 159 extension IP address, it's a load balancer which routes requests to multiple nodes. The nodes themselves do also have external IP addresses which they use for mining and inter-node comms, the 159 IP address is just for the benefit of the web extension so it has one point to talk to.

Yes there were quite a few forks yesterday but they seem to have been resolved now, you're correct that this will have been the cause of fluctuations in block era and wallet balances as different nodes behind the load balancer will not have necessarily agreed in real time on the state of a transaction, wallet, etc


[09-Aug-18 06:41 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
But yes this all seems to be stable today    There were some small adjustments pushed to Github which changed some timeout values which seems to have helped a bit, you can try and pull that from master but it's not at all required/urgent. The node dev team are currently working on a bunch of stability improvements as we speak

[27-Aug-18 06:59 AM] codybartfast#9308
Hi @Marcin,  my assumption is that this is the transaction fee pool.  Whenever somebody pays to put data on the Weave (or perhaps transfers AR) then the AR transaction fee gets added to reward pool and a fraction(?) of that pool is awarded to successful miners of new blocks.   The values are not as big as they seem, I think they're  in pico-AR (ie.  10 ^ -12).   If they're aren't many transactions then the pool gets emptied quite quickly, hence the 0 values.

[20-Sep-18 01:04 AM] codybartfast#9308
@Vilenarios  Just guessing... I would think the first priority for mining performance is having access to as much of the data of possible, if there were a choice between all the data a x1 speed vs half the data at x2 speed I'm pretty sure the first option is best.   Doubling the number of cores looks like it would also be far more beneficial than increasing disk speed.   However, the complicating factor is how the Wildfire protocol will work.  (iirc) it will reward responsive peers and so by inference would punish slow ones, but I doubt SSD is likely to be worth the cost (guess).  I still want one though!

[27-Sep-18 09:41 AM] arweave-sam#9630
@Joel those blocks are being written to disk again, yes, but they are not being redownload. The system picks a random block, 'gets' it (if on disk already it just reads locally, if not held locally it retreives it from a peer) then writes it to disk with the new format.

[28-Sep-18 01:32 PM] tiamat#9131
what is node_state_latency ?


[28-Sep-18 01:35 PM] Marcin#0065
After the 1.5 launch, will all block afterwards be smaller, or the block before too? 
Will there be any difference between deleti g 150gb of blocks and start over again?


[29-Sep-18 01:16 AM] arweave-sam#9630
> node_state_latency

This refers to the amount of time taken to contact the internal node processes of the host. Because the system is written in Erlang it is actually a large collection of asynchronous processes that handle different tasks. We use this metric to check that access to the core processes is still running smoothly.


[29-Sep-18 01:22 AM] arweave-sam#9630
> will all block afterwards be smaller, or the block before too? 

All blocks, before and after. You will get the new blocks faster if you convert, and subsequently spend some more time actively hashing.

For the Arweave.N.2 release we are working towards having the storage of the wallet lists completely optional for blocks more than 50 blocks old. This will cutdown on the storage overhead of the weave to the point that it is miniscule, freeing up space in the network for storage of actual data. Unlike 1.5 however, this further minification of blocks would not work on the previous blocks in the network, only new ones.

[29-Sep-18 03:44 AM] tiamat#9131
what is ADR%/NODE and POA RATE ?


[29-Sep-18 03:59 AM] arweave-sam#9630
ADR shows average replications of the blockweave (only polling our nodes at the moment -- the network stats on the upcoming site will ping all nodes). 100% implies that every node holds the full weave.

POA rate refers to the effective mining rate of the net in proof of access.

[05-Oct-18 03:03 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Also, an update regarding logging:

The latest development version of 1.5 now makes logging of interface checks optional (default off). This means that the many 'writing_block_to_disk' messages will not normally show, now. You can re-enable these messages (if you desire) by appending `enable disk_logging` to your command line arguments.


[05-Oct-18 03:04 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Further, if you would like to log http requests on the latest development version you can also add `enable http_logging`

By talking all time about an "dropbox-like" feature, arweave starts to compare itself to dropbox. An user interface to use it is a must to even try talk like that. But it all aint working well, if you have few people in the world, who are able to let a miner run (an here we get to the point of decentealization). So speaking of a decentralized storage project you MUST reach a lot miner around the globe who are willing to give disk space for the network. 
And here we start. Using ubuntu you eliminate already some part of the potential miner (but i dont think its a problem in here). Secondly, you type in the code, firstly you may think its working. But small issues like disconnects, may cause getting out of sync. 
But there are a lot people, who do not even know what git is for. 
If a new version comes out, you do not have the new files in the folders automatically. 
The way it is now, its either wont stand, coz too few miners are joined and not enough disk space will be left, or you gonna have very few miner mining and deciding whats in the weave. Not a good point to push adds for decentralized storage. 
We do not have a lot miner today, even weeks after mainnet launch. How do you imagine to stand a chance agains all the people tryying out to use the "dropbox like" feature, when it launches? Im afraid the first impression wont be good, coz it will be slow and expencive. And the first jmpression is very important in my mind.

Gui 2. basic settings like path to storage (why no multiple disk storage management?), adress, max cores, max storage etc. and 3. a simple "start mining" button. Everyone would join the network that way, coz its easier than all that terminal commands. Pls have in mind you want to reach people who never used a terminal nor ubuntu

[15-Oct-18 03:33 AM] codybartfast#9308
@Vilenarios, re running multiple miners on the same address but with different ports, ... I tested this a couple of months back and no, I couldn't use any port other than 1984.   I could bring up the server on a different port by specifying the startup parameter and that part worked fine.  But remote servers just ignored the port you were actually using so I never got responses back from other servers.   I did look at the code and it seemed the server just stored the remote address of peers not remote end-points (the combination of address and port).  Of course it could have been fixed since, but I doubt it's been a priority.


[15-Oct-18 03:44 AM] codybartfast#9308
@Joel, re having ar_cleanup only process larger files,  perhaps open this as a GitHub issue?  This might make a nice easy, low risk job for somebody wanting to make their first contribution to the project.  https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/issues

[15-Oct-18 04:20 AM] arweave-sam#9630
> you once said that with 2.0 wallet_lists will get smaller, significantly? could you give a %?

@tiamat The plan is that wallet lists older than 50 blocks should be completely optional. So from a space complexity POV we are going from Ospace(n) to Ospace(50).

[15-Oct-18 04:30 AM] arweave-sam#9630
>  Is there something obvious that I'm missing?

Even though you used the IP of a 1.5 node, you will only use that to download the first 50 blocks. After that you use the wider set of nodes that are available to you -- currently including many 1.1 nodes. After the 1.5 release has been deployed we will see how the download times look and go from there.

[15-Oct-18 11:00 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hi all, 1.5 RC-2 has now been released.

The key improvement since the RC-1 release is the addition of the `miner's log` on the main console. By default the node will now print to this console when it accepts a foreign block, or you mine a block. This should make it easier for miners to understand what their node is up to, without getting into the 'depths' of the system with the debugging log.

[15-Oct-18 11:37 PM] arweave-sam#9630
@Marcin As well as the fact that we expect the issue will resolve itself in a few days, the main concern I have is this:

Data distribution in the Arweave network is incentivised. If we (the Arweave project) get involved with producing and distributing blocks off-weave we could inadvertently tip the scales for miners in ways that we have tried very hard to avoid. I am happy to be pragmatic about it if we find that 1.5 does not sufficiently solve the block download problem, but until then I ask for your patience. Thanks.

[16-Oct-18 02:45 AM] codybartfast#9308
@Joel  I hope some of your mined blocks made it to the block explorer.  Only about half the blocks I mine survive.  I think it's quite common for two mines to mine a block at approximately the same time and ultimately only one will be chosen by the network,  if you lose the 'vote' then I think you'll see a fork recovery process kick off as your miner incorporates the other block.  I think the flip side of this is the "ignoring_block_below_current" message which is  when  somebody else has mined a block and you ignore it because you've already got a block from another mine.

[20-Oct-18 06:11 AM] arweave-sam#9630
@baz: I am afraid that I do not have time to go into the details today, but here is a quick answer: This is an off-net affair. In a theoretical situation in which mining pools have become common, miners would socially be able to see this (in the same way we all have awareness of the existence of Bitcoin pools by people using and talking about them), and the effect that it has on the weave. If a number of pools then shut down, we could see that blocks are becoming rarer again and subsequently the incentive to store them increases.

[21-Oct-18 04:50 AM] arweave-sam#9630
@patrick Yes, please! The graph would be interesting.

We have memory usage logging across all of our nodes and there does not appear to be a sustained incline. The system is pretty memory hungry in general, though. It seems that the Erlang VM is quite lazy about reclaiming memory from processes that are no longer using it, so we very quickly reach the memory high water mark level, but then the unused memory is reclaimed.

[22-Oct-18 01:45 AM] arweave-sam#9630
The issue regarding blocks being mined locally, but then not showing up on VB (etc), will be that the block you mined has not been accepted by the wider network. This is essentially because the connectivity based (Wildfire) part of the competition happens after that block mined message is shown. I will make a ticket for logging 10 blocks after one of your blocks has been mined that it was actually accepted by the network.


[22-Oct-18 01:46 AM] arweave-sam#9630
In order to optimise the number of your mined blocks being accepted, you need to compete with your connectivity. The faster your node replies to requests from others, the higher the likelihood that your block will be the one chosen by the network.


[22-Oct-18 01:48 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Improving the 'settlement time' of new blocks in the network (as we are planning to do so) will lower the randomness in this aspect of mining, but the core connectivity competition will remain.

[22-Oct-18 10:59 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Regarding seeing WF score, there isn't one single number that defines your score in the system, so we can't expose it directly. One of the three things we are working on this week to improve miner experience is publishing regular 'maps' of the WF network, so you can see where you are in reference to other nodes.


[22-Oct-18 11:01 AM] arweave-sam#9630
The other two things are a nice infographic that explains the different stages of mining an Arweave block, how you can optimise mining, and common pitfalls, as well as an improved miner log.


[22-Oct-18 11:02 AM] arweave-sam#9630
The new miner log will make it clear that just having mined a block is not enough -- it needs to be accepted, too. Where is where being a good citizen with WF is rewarded.


[22-Oct-18 11:03 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Not sure when the 'mining infographic' or new mining log will be out, but the first network maps should be with you later this week.


[22-Oct-18 11:06 AM] tiamat#9131
how about the memory ?  few days/weeks ago beam was sitting below 5% now jumping often to 30%


[22-Oct-18 11:06 AM] tiamat#9131
and many complained about this


[22-Oct-18 11:06 AM] tiamat#9131
any reason?


[22-Oct-18 11:10 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Erlang likes to hold memory until it runs low to avoid reallocs/frees. The console message is harmless unless you actually have a low memory machine (less than 8gb) -- it just frees memory only when it needs to. This  should not be a problem if you are using other programs on the system either, as Erlang will just be forced to garbage collect more frequently.


[22-Oct-18 11:11 AM] arweave-sam#9630
If this is an issue long term we can look at ways to constrain the memory of the Erlang VM.


[22-Oct-18 11:12 AM] tiamat#9131
To me it's concerning because I found it once with 100 blocks behind and a high watermark alert, the system has 32 GB


[22-Oct-18 11:13 AM] tiamat#9131
and it was pretty stuck, if it happens again I will take a closer look


[22-Oct-18 11:15 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Being 100 blocks behind is definitely concerning, but the high watermark is fair normal. By default the memory allocators seem very greedy (taking until they run out, then freeing as necessary).


[22-Oct-18 12:23 PM] yemboy#6783
Saw a block mined..got the reward and later disappeared

[23-Oct-18 10:16 AM] arweave-sam#9630
@Vilenarios you asked an interesting question earlier about our testing structure:

We start with a battery of ~125 tests that range from unit tests to 'tiny network tests'. The tiny network tests spawn many nodes inside the Erlang VM, manipulate the network into many different [often unusual] situations, then test the behaviour of the network. We then also have simulations of very large networks inside a single node, including network failure states, etc.

Once we are comfortable with the operation inside the machine, depending on the size of the update we might start a private inter-node network across a few machines. Once that is not displaying issues, we add a single node to the main network and monitor its activity for between 12 hours and 3 days. After that we have a set of canary nodes that we deploy to, again monitoring for errors. If it is a really big update (like `1.5-BETA-1`) we will deploy it to a further group of nodes, and continue monitoring.

Finally, after that we tag the release :).


[23-Oct-18 10:19 AM] arweave-sam#9630
In terms of monitoring, we have central log submission, so we can see what all of our nodes are doing, all the time. We then have a separate system that produces statistics and graphing based on those logs. In parallel, we have a graphing system for many 'vital signs' across the network -- from VM memory usage, to number of HTTP errors, etc.

[24-Oct-18 03:30 AM] codybartfast#9308
Hi guys, just some thoughts on cores:

My experience is that Erlang sees logical cores.  I.e., with 6 physical cores Erlang sees 12.  

I had to reduce it to 8 cores to get it consistently under 100% cpu (I think others have said the same).

I suspect consumer chips may be quite different from server chips. In my limited experience 'enterprise' chips can handle sustained heavy load much better than consumer chips, so high end chips might run more than 66% of the cores continuously.

But once I got the CPU below 100% my mine seems less erratic - but that might be taking credit away from team's improvements to the code.

Happy mining.


[24-Oct-18 03:33 AM] codybartfast#9308
@WILL ,  to set the wallet address for mining rewards add ` mining_addr  --your-wallet-address-here-- ` to the startup command.  But my guess is that is not related to the log message you quoted.

[29-Oct-18 06:11 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hi guys,

`N.1.5.0.0-RC-5` is now out. You can update your miners by running `git fetch --all ; git checkout N.1.5.0.0-RC-5 ; git pull`.

Highlights from this release:
- New miner log that makes the progression through the three phases of Arweave mining clearer. This log also now monitors the node's connectivity, printing a warning if inbound communications halt.
- Misc network transfer performance improvements.

A special thanks goes to our community testers! @Marcin @Dentechr @Mike

[29-Oct-18 12:19 PM] ATLAS#7218
@awkweird It's randomly mined.


[29-Oct-18 12:20 PM] ATLAS#7218
If you successfully find the properly hashed candidate block before anyone else and distribute across the network, you will get the reward.


[29-Oct-18 12:21 PM] ATLAS#7218
And of course, finding a properly hashed block is pure *luck* because of the randomness by sha384.


[29-Oct-18 12:23 PM] ATLAS#7218
@arweave-india @Vilenarios I believe he asked the interval he mines a block. Not time taken for reward to come after mining


[29-Oct-18 12:23 PM] ATLAS#7218
Viewblock will say you have received the block if it is on the same fork as you. In other words, when you find a candidate block, you have your reward in your *local* blockweave but its just not confirmed. So reward is actually immediately distributed.

[31-Oct-18 11:10 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey gang, some thoughts/answers to some of the above:

> I wonder if some sort of dynamic DNS could be incorporated.

@Mike Yes, we will be looking at this.

> announced their hashrates, which would probably be a nice feature to have.
> blocks paired to IPs would be a big concern to decentralization and privacy
> i still dont want people to know my IP/wallet size

Yep, the way I see it at the moment nodes on the network should not be broadcasting any data that may identify them as a large miner of blocks. The main issue I am concerned about is that miners may keep large wallets on machine's that are publicly accessible via IP, making them a target for attack.


[31-Oct-18 11:10 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We could look at making your hash rate or mining address public optionally, at some point, but my guess is that if you had to manually turn it on people simply wouldn't use it


[31-Oct-18 11:10 AM] arweave-sam#9630
So it wouldn't be effective anyway


[31-Oct-18 11:17 AM] Vilenarios#8742
Sam do you envision some kind of load/tx test on the network?


[31-Oct-18 11:23 AM] rehash#3438
it's not only about wallet hacks, strong miners could become victims of DDOS attacks so others can get those rewards while down


[31-Oct-18 11:24 AM] arweave-sam#9630
@rehash Both are best avoided ;)

@Vilenarios Yes, sometime after 1.6 we will look at doing this on the main net, test nets until then.

[01-Nov-18 10:36 AM] arweave-sam#9630
> solve a block, send it out to close peers, immediately start hashing on the next one before everyone else...

I think that this is largely correct -- you get a natural advantage of a few seconds mining if you mine the previous block yourself (as everyone else has to check and adopt it first). The 'streakiness' should amortise out as the number of large miners in the network increases.


[01-Nov-18 10:37 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Regarding pool mechanics, I do not think that this would be healthy at this stage. It is up to the community to decide of course, but we won't be building support for it ourselves for a little while.

[05-Nov-18 08:15 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@WILL Here are three of our nodes you can use. Keep in mind that you are trusting the nodes by starting from them, so only use ours if you trust us.

54.93.54.173:1984

[05-Nov-18 08:16 AM] arweave-sam#9630
@Vilenarios -- indeed, this is only the peer that you trust to download the block hash list from.


[05-Nov-18 08:17 AM] arweave-sam#9630
The block hash list tells you the 'state of the network'. With it, you can verify all of the data contained within the weave (all of the other data is cryptographically related).


[05-Nov-18 08:18 AM] arweave-sam#9630
After you download the first 100 blocks, the trusted peers are the same as the untrusted ones  


[05-Nov-18 08:27 AM] Vilenarios#8742
Thank you Sam. 🙏🏻 How is node state latency calculated?


[05-Nov-18 08:30 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We send a message from the HTTP worker process (that you spawn on the node when you send a message) through the processes that perform book keeping in your node, then back to the HTTP process, then report the time that that takes


[05-Nov-18 08:31 AM] Vilenarios#8742
Wow so it’s all internally calculated and has nothing to do with the actual network?


[05-Nov-18 08:32 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Yes, that is the internal book keeping process latency


[05-Nov-18 08:33 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We put it in the stats mostly for our internal use when monitoring the network -- we didn't expect people to pay so much attention to it, although it does act as a pretty good 'node health indicator'.


[05-Nov-18 08:35 AM] Vilenarios#8742
Well as I understand it, the higher latency means longer it takes to receive updates and requests on the network.


[05-Nov-18 08:35 AM] Vilenarios#8742
But it shouldn’t affect distribution of a new block right?


[05-Nov-18 08:36 AM] Vilenarios#8742
Because that is a distribution as opposed to http request. And the miner shouldn’t be running during block distribution right?


[05-Nov-18 08:38 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Mining and block distribution are concurrent processes, so they will both happen at (or around) the same time


[05-Nov-18 08:38 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Meaning the the performance of one (or the book keeping around it) will affect the performance of the other


[05-Nov-18 08:38 AM] Vilenarios#8742
Got it


[05-Nov-18 08:40 AM] Vilenarios#8742
This whole time I’m like thinking my ISP is throttling my network but node state latency has nothing to do with actual bandwidth!

[07-Nov-18 10:08 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hi all,

`N.1.5.0.0-RC-6` is now out! You can check it out by running `git fetch --all ; git checkout N.1.5.0.0-RC-6`.

Highlights from this release:
- Improved block read from disk speed, resulting in substantially faster (~60-70%) block adoption and fork recovery processes.
- Optimised memory usage mechanics, resulting in ~80% memory usage reduction on some nodes.
- The `GET /metrics` endpoint is now optional. Add `disable metrics` to your command line options to prohibit it.

Thanks as always to our community testers!

{Reactions}

[13-Nov-18 12:50 AM] Marcin#0065
Hmm, as far i understand, it all depends on ur internet connection much. In case ur having a good connection, u also need to compete against miners, who are in the network much longer and have a higher wildfire score (better latency and so on). Furthermore u are allowee to take part in the hashing, if u have the random recall block, so u need to download all blocks first to be fully mining. 
In case ur all food with that, a good multicore cpu (lets say 12 cores) may get you 2-3 blocks a day?

[14-Nov-18 10:23 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey guys,

The 1.5.0.0 final release has now been tagged. There were no changes between the sixth release candidate and the final release (apart from the release and version numbers).

1.5 feature recap:
- ~95% reduction in block size
- ~95% reduction in network traffic
- 5-10x faster block verification
- New miner-friendly logging

In total, the 1.5 release has 17,500 individual line changes from the prior major release.

Thanks again to all of our community testers! It is exciting to see our community grow as it has over the last month or so.

Looking ahead:

1.6: The first fork of the Arweave network.

We are well on the way to delivering ‘blockweave 2.0’, the focus of our work since the launch of the main net back in June. The first stage of this journey, ‘tiny-blocks’, was shipped as part of version 1.5. Version 1.6 will perform a small protocol upgrade at block height 95,000, implementing the following features:
- Minor changes to the difficulty algorithm.
- Faster independent hash verification.
- Unbalanced merkle tree roots for O(1) block hash list verification.
- Redistribution of block rewards not distributed in the soft-on-boarding period across the rest of year one, inline with our originally published inflation schedule.

How will this work?

The Arweave team will send you an email (as well as a message here) a few thousand blocks before the upgrade takes place. You will then need to update and restart your miner. Once the appropriate height is reached, the new features will come into effect.

[19-Nov-18 03:59 AM] Marcin#0065
Every time a new block has to be mined, a so called recall block is chosen randomnly. If you own the recall block, you are qualified to start hashing. The more space you have, the more blocks you can keep, therefore you can start mining more often. Space and cpu power are both important. Also a good internet connection is recommendet.

[22-Nov-18 03:10 PM] chriscord#4741
I've seen some mentions of "port forwarding" in previous discussions. Is this something the installer takes care of automatically or do I have to manually configure this? 

And if I have to, what should I do to configure it? Thanks


[22-Nov-18 03:28 PM] arweave-martin#1169
@chriscord  You need to make sure that the mining machine is reachable on TCP port 1984 from the Internet. So, if your miner is on a local network (i.e. behind a NAT), you need to configure your gateway to forward port 1984 to the miner's local IP address.


[22-Nov-18 08:57 PM] chriscord#4741

[23-Nov-18 01:05 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey all,

Just a reminder that the version 1.6 protocol upgrade is scheduled for block 95,000 (estimated for 6am CET on Monday 2nd). We will be releasing the 1.6.0 client early next week, after which you will need to upgrade your mining client. We will keep you informed as things progress.

A brief recap of the new features in 1.6:

- Extremely fast ( _O_(1), for the nerds like us   ) independent hash and block list verification.
- Tweaks to the difficulty adjustment algorithm.
- Redistribution of soft on-boarding rewards over Y1.

Have a great weekend and happy mining!

-arweave-dev-team

[28-Nov-18 10:51 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey @everyone ,

Arweave N.1.6.0.0 has now been released! You will need to make sure your miner is upgraded before block 95,000, when the new features will be activated.

You can update your miner by running:

`git fetch --all ; git checkout master ; git reset --hard N.1.6.0.0`

The new features in 1.6:

- Extremely fast ( O(1) ) independent hash and block list verification.
- Tweaks to the difficulty adjustment algorithm.
- Redistribution of soft on-boarding rewards over Y1 (in ‘network time’).

Bonus: A wallet name generator that allows you to find addresses that start with a given prefix.

Competition: We will be giving away 250 AR to the wallet with the ‘best’ name (completely subjective decision of the team, sorry XD) to mine a block before the activation of 1.6 at 95,000. Get generating!

{Reactions}
  

[28-Nov-18 11:08 AM] arweave-sam#9630
To generate a new wallet with a name that you are looking for, type the following after starting your node:

`app_namer:start(["pre1", "pre2", "pre3"], 4, l33t).` <ENTER>

Where 'pre1-3' are prefix strings for wallet addresses that you would like to find and 4 is the number of processes (subsequently, cores) to use to find the named wallet. The final argument is the type of dictionary to use: l33t ('text' speak, fastest to find, lowest quality), normal (matches without case), and strict (matches only exact strings).

[21-Dec-18 03:17 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@Marcin  we are working on a mechanism that will allow you to never store and serve particular data even if it is already a part of the weave.

I agree, we need to document the current firewall as well as the future algorithm for miners.


[21-Dec-18 03:30 AM] Marcin#0065
But how will that correlate with mining? If lets say 40% of the blocks are full of bad data i want to block , which is considered as bad by the community as well, therefore i am not able to mine 40% of the time due to not owning recall blocks?


[21-Dec-18 03:31 AM] Marcin#0065
In such case, my motivation to dump bad data is low, when i want to mine more effectively


[21-Dec-18 03:36 AM] arweave-lev#3466
Every miner has a choice. The important points are 1) you should have an option to opt out from storing and serving certain data; you are not responsible for what other miners do 2) the incentives make it unlikely for the whole network to lose a certain piece of data; although even then there are ways out 3) in general, it's a fundamental tradeoff the censorship-free ecosystem has to face and find its equilibrium point.


[21-Dec-18 04:48 AM] 2072 [ANFRA]#9291

This way nodes would be also able to use this score to filter content servicing automatically or not...

[22-Dec-18 12:48 AM] ivhturp#3325
@tiamat Thanks for reply. Even though content policy exists, identifying illicit content is a challenge. 
Its true that existing clouds are not aware of the content. I believe addressing this issue will be a key concern before the momentum picks up for decentralised storage


[22-Dec-18 10:36 AM] arweave-martin#1169
