@slayer_hellraiser  when you join the weave, the node downloads the last 50 blocks and stops there. It does not attempt to download older blocks. Older blocks still slowly arrive as recall blocks so that the node can validate them though.

[02-Jan-19 03:14 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@slayer_hellraiser the base reward is now around 35 AR, as @Vilenarios has pointed out. It slowly changes over time according to a function of height - https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/N.1.6.0.0/src/ar_inflation.erl#L33. You get additional reward if you include transactions, the amount increases with the transaction size.

[02-Jan-19 06:38 AM] arweave-lev#3466
The dependency on the data size is not linear. Starting from 10MB the prices grow exponentially to respect the optimal network throughput. It is prohibitively expensive to post a single huge tx to the network. On the other hand posting 1000 1MB transactions should cost around 120 AR. You can find more details here - https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/N.1.6.0.0/src/ar_tx.erl#L204. Also, there is an HTTP endpoint giving estimations: /price/<size-in-bytes>. It responds with a price in Winston so divide by 1000000000000.

 
https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/N.1.6.0.0/src/ar_tx.erl
ArweaveTeam/arweave
The Arweave server and App Developer Toolkit. Contribute to ArweaveTeam/arweave development by creating an account on GitHub.

[06-Jan-19 02:01 PM] arweave-martin#1169
@Vilenarios Are you referring to "node_state_latency"? node_state_latency is the latency in microseconds when fetching something from the state storage inside the arweave server. It has nothing to do with network since it's completely internal. I guess the name is not very clear.


[06-Jan-19 02:17 PM] Vilenarios#8742

[21-Jan-19 05:55 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@awkweird @ivhturp Good to know is that the Wildfire score is based on the IP address. When you change IP address, all other nodes will see your node as a new one. This will basically reset your Wildfire scores.


[21-Jan-19 06:01 AM] Vilenarios#8742
Is there a “maximum” wildfire score?


[21-Jan-19 06:10 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@Vilenarios  I don't know for sure,  but I'm guessing no because that doesn't make sense to me. Keep in mind that every node peering with your node will keep its own score for your node. The absolute value of your score doesn't matter. If your node has the best score, then a higher score wont make a difference.


[21-Jan-19 06:21 AM] ivhturp#3325
How do i check wildfire score of my nodes. And what impact can it have on candidate blocks that are produced?


[21-Jan-19 06:23 AM] ivhturp#3325
Is it less probable for a candidate block of a new node to be accepted?


[21-Jan-19 06:36 AM] Vilenarios#8742
All my candidate blocks are always accepted unless it’s a polling node.


[21-Jan-19 06:36 AM] awkweird#6550
The IP got static but the instance often restarts and need to do the work all over again. Any specific configuration for setting the miner in aws?


[21-Jan-19 06:44 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@ivhturp The nodes don't expose the score of their peers, so you cannot see what scores your node has on the network. You can read about how Wildfire works in the Lightpaper https://www.arweave.org/files/arweave-lightpaper.pdf


[21-Jan-19 06:49 AM] arweave-martin#1169
The point of Wildfire is to incentivise providing other nodes with data quickly (including fast propagation of new blocks). If your node is a good citizen distributing data quickly to the network, then other nodes will distribute data quickly to your node. The quicker you get new blocks, the less time your miner is spending on mining on the wrong block.


[21-Jan-19 06:49 AM] arweave-martin#1169
Read more about it in the Lightpaper.

[30-Jan-19 11:11 AM] Marcin#0065
Whats the relation between 1 core and 1 core with 2 threads?


[30-Jan-19 11:12 AM] tiamat#9131
they are seen by erlang as different vcpus


[30-Jan-19 11:12 AM] Marcin#0065
The benchmark on my pc loads one thread only


[30-Jan-19 11:13 AM] Marcin#0065
So the benchmark gives a thread score, not cpu core score?


[30-Jan-19 11:13 AM] tiamat#9131
a 4core intel with 2 hyperthreads would be seen as 8 vcpus

[30-Jan-19 11:23 AM] tiamat#9131
and one about Hashpower reuse


[30-Jan-19 11:23 AM] tiamat#9131
Hashpower reuse technique

A key observation from this list is that BTC/ETH has very strong hashpower but with lower number of transactions per second. Is it possible that new blockchains could reuse the hashpower of BTC/ETH to prevent double-spending attacks, like code reuse in software development? One possible solution is to use sidechains, where the block producers (BP) of the sidechain periodically submit their chain snapshot to the mainchain (BTC/ETH). However, the consensus of the mainchain is not aware of the underlying sidechain consensus, and thus if different views are created in the sidechain, i.e., forks, the sidechain has to decide the correct view by the sidechain’s own consensus algorithm, which weakens the security model.


[30-Jan-19 11:25 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Thanks @tiamat, very interesting

[31-Jan-19 05:20 AM] ATLAS#7218
To put it simply, if you have *M* blocks out of total *N* blocks, you will have *M/N* probability to start competing for the next block. For people who just started, *M << N* so its very unlikely to be eligible to mine the next block.

[01-Feb-19 03:46 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@ivhturp there is an HTTP endpoint that might help to automate this process - https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/master/src/ar_http_iface_server.erl#L425. Unfortunately, it's not documented. Anyway, it's easy to use. From the node with a new dynamic IP, make `POST /peers` HTTP requests to the nodes you want to peer with. The body should contain the network name, like this: `{"network":"arweave.N.1"}` .  An example using curl: `curl -X POST -d '{"network":"arweave.N.1"}' http://127.0.0.1:1984/peers`.

 
https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/master/src/ar_http_iface_server.erl
ArweaveTeam/arweave
The Arweave server and App Developer Toolkit. Contribute to ArweaveTeam/arweave development by creating an account on GitHub.
https://images-ext-2.discordapp.net/external/_8TDpxMXAdEmFWMsJ8MvVUfQdHCK4hLlEBp2qBfICb8/%3Fs%3D400%26v%3D4/https/avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/31965957

==> Caveats
Man pages can be found in:
  /usr/local/opt/erlang@20/lib/erlang/man

Access them with `erl -man`, or add this directory to MANPATH.

erlang@20 is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because this is an alternate version of another formula.

If you need to have erlang@20 first in your PATH run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/erlang@20/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bash_profile

For compilers to find erlang@20 you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/erlang@20/lib"

[19-Feb-19 05:27 AM] arweave-martin#1169
Hi @courtcircuit ! I recognise that crash. I'm guessing you have a big machine (i.e. many CPU cores) and don't specify the `max_miners` startup argument to `arweave-server`. What happens is that you will get high response times internally in the node, and eventually this timeout happens.


[19-Feb-19 05:27 AM] arweave-martin#1169
How many CPU cores do you have?


[19-Feb-19 05:28 AM] arweave-martin#1169
It's a known issue which we will address eventually.


[19-Feb-19 05:29 AM] arweave-martin#1169
You can see the current response time by browsing to `/info` and check the `node_state_latency` metric. It's in micro-seconds, so it can be a quite high value.


[19-Feb-19 05:29 AM] arweave-martin#1169
I think the timeout happens at 5s.


[19-Feb-19 05:30 AM] gucceed#9385
Its an i5core.What does this mean for me


[19-Feb-19 05:36 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@Mazzz I quickly checked the code. It makes the assumption that everything is stored on the same filesystem, so the limit of disk space used doens't work with symlinks. I would recommend you to not enable the `disk_space` limit and just make sure you have enough free space.


[19-Feb-19 05:41 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@gucceed Homebrew didn't link erlang@20 for you since it's keg only (which it says in the output). I force-link it on my Macs like this: `brew link erlang@20 --force`


[19-Feb-19 05:42 AM] Mazzz#1871

[19-Feb-19 05:44 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@courtcircuit It's much better to make your node accessible directly by other nodes than running in polling mode. Can you open up port 1984 on you Internet IP address so it goes to your miner? In that case you don't need polling mode and shouldn't use it. You can also choose another port with the `port x` argument to `arweave-server`.

[19-Feb-19 11:11 AM] arweave-sophie#4476
Because of the way that the Arweave proof of access system works, miners are favourably rewarded for offering hard drive space above raw hashing power, meaning that efficient miners will optimise on this variable first. You can find out more about mining optimisation here: https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/optimisation-tips

 
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/optimisation-tips
https://images-ext-2.discordapp.net/external/G8HLYFWMprhy7yK2e31zT0zItU5ekMF6HVGvcVWZzM4/https/www.gitbook.com/share/space/thumbnail/-LRMphNRIDGSg4iSR6kj.png


[19-Feb-19 11:16 AM] arweave-sophie#4476
It's actually port forwarding which is the issue here @nijntje , not your internet connection. We will revise the copy on this warning message. You can address this by configuring port forwarding on your router and ensuring that port 1984 is not blocked by your firewall :blockchain:


[19-Feb-19 11:16 AM] nijntje#0173

[19-Feb-19 11:19 AM] arweave-sophie#4476

[22-Feb-19 12:20 PM] arweave-sophie#4476
The hashing algorithm used underneath the proof of access mechanism in the Arweave is SHA2-384, for which the CPU is the most efficient miner currently available. So essentially, miners should focus first on storage, then on hashing. We also intend to move to genprog which will render GPUs ineffective @necovx

[25-Feb-19 02:48 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@ivhturp

When a new block is mined, the node takes the first 10 best peers and sends the block to all of them in parallel. Afterward, it sends the block to rest of its peers one by one, in the wildfire score order. The motivation behind it is to make nodes mutually benefit from the good behavior - if you send your blocks and transactions promptly to others, they will do the same to you. Every node is interested in receiving blocks as fast as possible so that it can mine on top of the most relevant block.

When you receive a block, the wildfire score of the sender does not make a difference.

Note that difficulty 34 makes it 4 times harder to mine compared to difficulty 32. The network has grown a little so the difficulty might be 33 or 34 more often, what would explain the decreasing rewards.

Hope it helps.


[25-Feb-19 03:00 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@awkweird

Your block(s) have probably been orphaned. It happens every once in a while when two miners mine two blocks around the same time. One of those two gets abandoned by the network.


[25-Feb-19 03:31 AM] awkweird#6550

[25-Feb-19 05:30 PM] Vilenarios#8742
Does wildfire start from 0 every time a node restarts?


[26-Feb-19 02:26 AM] arweave-lev#3466
Other nodes do not reset your score if you restart, but the restarting node's scores will be reset and recomputed after a restart.


[26-Feb-19 03:44 AM] arweave-martin#1169
So basically, you only harm other nodes scores by restarting your node. But, since the other nodes like your node already (and are sending it blocks and transactions), your node will soon like them back.

[06-Mar-19 10:03 AM] arweave-lev#3466
Today we are happy to announce the release 1.6.2.0 of the Arweave Node!

We have
- Significantly increased the efficiency of block and transaction propagation.
- Sped up the fork recovery process.
- Added a `GET /wallet/[Addr]/deposits` endpoint for fetching incoming transfers for a wallet. For more details, see https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/N.1.6.2.0/http_iface_docs.md.
- Fixed a bug in the `POST /unsigned_tx` endpoint where it required irrelevant data. The updated endpoint documentation is at https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/N.1.6.2.0/http_post_unsigned_tx_docs.md.
- Made various reliability improvements.

Upgrade instructions:

1. Shut down `arweave-server`.
2. `git fetch --all --tags && git checkout master && git reset --hard N.1.6.2.0`
3. Start `arweave-server` again with the same arguments as before.

For more details on how to run the node, please see our mining guide -
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide.

Pay attention to the recommended list of peers. It has not been updated since the last release. These peers are all operated by the Arweave organization.

And a little bonus for those willing to contribute - we have prepared a simple guide for external contributors - https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md, check it out!


[06-Mar-19 10:11 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@here See the release notes above.

@yidakee Use the `max_miners` startup argument. E.g. `./arweave-server mine peer x.x.x.xx max_miners 2`

[08-Mar-19 12:03 PM] arweave-martin#1169
@Dentechr @yidakee In the latest release there is an improvement reducing the priority of the mining processes, so the latency should be less affected when mining with many cores.


[08-Mar-19 12:05 PM] arweave-martin#1169
@yidakee Try setting `max_miners 4` and see how it behaves. As long as the `node_state_latency` metric on the `/info` endpoint doesn't increase much, then it should be fine.

To start introductory:
There are 6 groups of dedicated servers (not VPS), on which Arweave mining was launched at different times. The number of servers in each group is the same.
1 group started the very first 2 months ago, 6 group started a few days ago.
On all servers, the blocks and transactions was updated, currently the volume of the arweave folder is 54373 MB on each server.
Servers are absolutely identical, groups 4-6 have never even been in operation.
On all servers almost simultaneously similar entries appear in the log:
Friday, 06:22:11: [Stage 1/3] Successfully proved access to recall block. Starting to hash.
and it basically says that the probability of block extraction is the same on all servers (correct me if I'm wrong), and the size of the folder with the blocks is the same everywhere, the value of "height" and "blocks" are about the same on all servers. Servers are rebooted at the same time, if necessary, and mining is simultaneously launched on them. There are no downtime in mining, the average CPU load is about the same for each server.
The number of rewards from the moment of full synchronization of servers from 4-6 groups for a rather long period is uneven (although over a large period it should be approximately the same):
Group_1 = 9 blocks
Group_2 = 13 blocks
Group_3 = 9 blocks
Group_4 = 3 blocks
Group_5 = 2 blocks
Group_6 = 3 blocks

Actually the question:
How is the reward accrued, if the differences are only in the time of the total mining of each server? For some reason, in two absolutely identical server groups, the number of found blocks may differ by 4-6 times? Does the number of rewards depend on the total time of the server as a miner?
P.S.:I repeat, all servers are exactly the same.

[19-Mar-19 10:20 AM] ATLAS#7218
Depends on your current wildfire most probably. If your current wildfire is very good, nodes will try to reach you often which in turn will lower your wildfire more rapidly in other nodes.


[19-Mar-19 10:20 AM] ATLAS#7218
So its more like exponential decay


[19-Mar-19 10:21 AM] ATLAS#7218
And its hard to say exactly because each node has different wildfire score of your node.

[22-Mar-19 05:26 AM] gcc_awe#8400
hello guys, I think it is freckly question
i keep going geting this 
 could_not_start_mining
    stored_recall_block_for_foreign_verification
and just wondering what is should do?


[22-Mar-19 05:36 AM] arweave-martin#1169
Hi @gcc_awe! Please note this is not an error message, just information in the log. To be able to participate in mining, you need to have the so called recall block. If you have 10% of all blocks, then it's 10% chance you will be able to mine the next block. If you browse to the `/info` endpoint on your miner, then you will see the "blocks" metrics witch tells you how many blocks your miner has stored on disk currently. It's also downloading random blocks in the background all the time.


[22-Mar-19 05:39 AM] arweave-martin#1169
The reason Arweave is using this recall block is to incentivise miners to store blocks. You can read more about it in the lightpaper. This log message is also explained in our mining guide https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide

 
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide
Mining Guide
Want to start mining on Arweave? You've come to the right place! Get set up with this quick and easy guide, and join our awesome network of ever-growing miners.
https://images-ext-2.discordapp.net/external/G8HLYFWMprhy7yK2e31zT0zItU5ekMF6HVGvcVWZzM4/https/www.gitbook.com/share/space/thumbnail/-LRMphNRIDGSg4iSR6kj.png

[04-Apr-19 05:23 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@here Today we are happy to announce the release 1.6.3 of the Arweave Node!

In it:

1. The `block/hash/[hash]` and `block/height/[height]` HTTP endpoints do not return a hash list by default anymore. Viewing blocks in a browser/other HTTP client is now much faster!
2. Reliability improvements of the time measurement for difficulty adjustments.
3. Various reliability improvements for the mining worker processes.
4. New mining benchmark tool, using real candidate block production to measure mining performance much more accurately. You can run it with `./arweave-server benchmark`.Note: As the new benchmarking tool tests real block production speed, not just pure hashing power, it may appear that the effective hashing rate has decreased. This is false. As it happens, the changes mentioned in point 3 lead to improved mining performance.

Upgrade instructions:

1. Shut down arweave-server. To make sure the shutdown was successful, run `ps aux | grep beam`. The output should only have a single line with `grep beam` at the end.
2. git fetch --all --tags && git checkout master && git reset --hard N.1.6.3.1
3. Start arweave-server again with the same arguments as before.

For more details on how to run the node, please see our mining guide -                                                 
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide.

Pay attention to the recommended list of peers. It has not been updated since the last release. These peers are all operated by the Arweave organization, so use them if you trust them - alternatively join on the IP address of another trusted node.

{Reactions}

[26-Apr-19 05:22 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey @ivhturp , @lvb , @rehash , yes we also received one of these yesterday. We have carefully reviewed and found no corresponding outbound traffic from our servers which matches the complaint. I believe that @rehash also performed such a review and did not find any corroborating evidence.

It appears that one of the miners in the network has been sending some of these complaints to the hosting providers of other nodes in order to try and pressure them into turning off their miners and lowering the difficulty. It is our understanding that (depending on jurisdiction) the providers must inform the server operators if they receive such a complaint, but they will not move forward with further action before corroborating that the server has indeed actually been involved in nefarious activities.

[27-Apr-19 12:14 AM] ivhturp#3325
@arweave-lev Will mentioning a peer while starting arweave-server have any positive impact on wildfire score of that peer in shortterm or longterm?


[27-Apr-19 06:57 AM] arweave-lev#3466
It might have a small impact short-term (first hours may be) as these are the first good (if they are good) peers your node learns about. But then it should not make any difference.


[27-Apr-19 06:57 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Yep, @ivhturp you will prefer those nodes for a short time, but it won't affect how much those nodes 'like' you


[27-Apr-19 08:46 PM] ivhturp#3325

[28-Apr-19 03:37 AM] courtcircuit#8002
morning @arweave-martin I saw difficulty has increased quite a bit but I haven't had anything in the last two weeks at all.... is that normal ?


[28-Apr-19 06:11 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@ivhturp there is no supported way to do this. It kinda breaks the idea of favoring closer peers over the remoter ones. It should not be beneficial not only in general but for your nodes specifically since they would spend time transferring their blocks somewhere far thus spending time and bandwidth that could be otherwise used for maintaining the good score with the close neighbors to learn about their blocks faster.

[08-Jan-18 05:11 AM] tierralibre#2740
I have been looking at the code I come from elixir. Trying to understand how the message passing works in a real network. Because I see messages are being passed between process. But this I assume can not happen when the network is distributed. How is that done? Just using the HTTP API?


[08-Jan-18 08:28 AM] Marcin#0065
Hey Guys, have you decided what algorithm you gonna use? U mentioned cuckoo cycle or other memory bandwith depdndant alg. Any news on that?


[08-Jan-18 12:18 PM] WillRogerJones#8527
@tierralibre Yes! This is actually quite an interesting part of the architecture. Essentially our message gossiping library (ar_gossip) has a bridge that allows the sending of messages between machines in the network (through the HTTP interface you mention). This means that sending messages between miners, apps, and services inside a single node is the same as sending messages to remote nodes, from the standpoint of the programmer. This has numerous benefits, particularly in the development of Archain apps.

@Marcin: We are still considering this, as it is an important decision (although the necessary edits to the codebase are small). We will let you know when we come to a conclusion!


[08-Jan-18 12:24 PM] tierralibre#2740
this is what I was trying to understand.   as well I am trying to see how I can use elixir to develop archain. is a very clean language

[14-Jan-18 03:36 PM] Marcin#0065
Hey guys, is there any update about the mining algorithm? what are your thoughts? what is the best/fairest one? There are many Projects around using computing power for scientific research, which allows almost any kind of computer device take part in it. Do you think archain could use that too? woudl suck, if big mining farms would dominate and influence the project :/


[16-Jan-18 10:59 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Hi @Marcin


[16-Jan-18 10:59 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
We've actually been talking about this a lot between ourselves, it's a very interesting question


[16-Jan-18 11:00 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
We too, see the problem of the centralisation of of computing power as a real potential problem - particularaly in a project such as Archain that is so reliant on geographic distribution for security


[16-Jan-18 11:01 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Not that SHA2 doesn't offer benefits though - it's been extensively tried and tested and to some extent, the best way to defend the network is to have all of this hashing power because it makes a 51% attack so much harder to pull off


[16-Jan-18 11:03 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Another problem with SHA is the longevity of the project


[16-Jan-18 11:03 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
We want Archain to be able to be up and running in 50 years or 100 years


[16-Jan-18 11:03 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
SHA might be the most widely used hashing algorithm at the moment, but I really doubt it's going to last that long


[16-Jan-18 11:03 AM] tierralibre#2740
then u need quantum level security


[16-Jan-18 11:04 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Yes, that would be ideal :p


[16-Jan-18 11:04 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
One alternative we considered is cuckoo cycle


[16-Jan-18 11:06 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Since it's based on finding cycles in graphs, it's a very difficult problem to crack even with advanced computing power


[16-Jan-18 11:07 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
and ultimately, its constrained by bus size


[16-Jan-18 11:07 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Making it very difficult to create any kind of specialist hardware


[16-Jan-18 11:08 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
However, I believe that the way the graphs are generated using hashing, so we'll have to think very carefully about that long term

[07-Apr-18 02:37 PM] digamma889#3785
Let me start by saying I'm no expert but as Arweave is focussing on the long long term it is probably going to face the introduction of stable quantum computing and the requirement to upgrade the cryptographic hash functions (as SHA-256 is being used if I'm correct) to post quantum secure hash functions.
Is this something that has crossed your minds already?


[09-Apr-18 04:45 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hi @digamma889 , indeed it has! The answer is slightly broader though: how do we cope with breaks of the underlying cryptographic functions in general? Our approach is to have a system of 'tagging' of support for protocol change proposals in new blocks and transactions.

Users will be able to upload protocol upgrade proposals to the network (similar to RFCs, but with added implementation deadlines). Miners can then add 'tags' to their blocks that state their support (or dissent) for a given proposal (refered to by its Arweave TX ID). Users can also add tags to their transactions that signal similar support.

After network launch we will be running a website (a typical Arweave app node) that displays these support and dissent tags for the various proposals, allowing miners and users to decide if and when to implement the upgrades. Being open source, members of the community will be able to submit changes, fork, and run their own monitors that display the information in different forms.

So... in the context of quantum resistance, we expect that there will be at least some warning about when the problem is likely to arrive. At that time, the Arweave project will write a proposal regarding potential protocol upgrades (members of the community will be free to do the same), miners and users will 'vote with their feet' and the changes will be adopted once broad consensus (potentially after refinements) is reached.

[14-May-18 06:03 PM] Vadim | NEAR#8313
@WillRogerJones could you please answer to previous message?


[15-May-18 03:20 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
@mattr  Yes! Those are exactly the kind of projects we see Arweave being useful for.


@Vadim | NEAR l, Of course, sorry for the wait.

There are no such things as smart contracts in Arweave at the moment. Storage in Arweave isn't based on the renting storage model that filecoin and sia are, it's based on a new model that utlises our new Proof of Access algorithm. In short, it incentivises storage of old data by making it a necessary requirement for mining new blocks.

It's this structure that makes us unique from sia and filecoin, and that lets us provide better prices for long term file storage.


[15-May-18 09:56 AM] mattr#1108

So it might be a hybrid or cold storage at some point. But wouldn't be very feasible on a public blockchain for the content itself.  we're still evaluating options - but right now it's looking like leveraging the public ethereum chain is not the best way to go due to gas charges. we're looking at a few options, all would be linked back to the public mainnet by way of hash or something similar. options include 1) IPFS or other flat file storage, 2) some distributed DB such as bigchaindb or bluzelle, 3) running a private net in parallel.  so I let them know about your project.

[18-May-18 06:14 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
hi @helloworld 

No, you're not missing anything. 5000 TPS - or even more - is certainly possible in a well connected network as described, but you're correct in saying that we can't break the laws of physics; with a 1mb/s connection we certainly can't push 5000 transactions at a few kilobytes to the whole network every second.

Our testnets are a good example, as you say. This is a much less optimal environment with many participants with poor connections, and I wouldn't expect the upper limit to be able to exceed 100-200 TPS - depending on the connection strengths of our participants.


[18-May-18 06:15 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
@mattr mattr Yes! We've got several partnerships in the works here, keep an eye on our blog for more details about these.

[25-May-18 09:07 AM] Krypto Light#1198
Due to the lightpaper quite short, I am confusing at some points

1. In the blockweave, do you store the detail of all transactions or only store the list of hash values of previous blocks and wallets?

2. Assume that I have a text file, where do you store my file? blockweare or node or local?

3. You mention that the miner no need to store full blockweare, who will maintain the full blockweave? 

4. Could you please explain the claimed: "As the amount of data stored in the system increases, the amount of hashing needed for consensus decreases, thus reducing the cost of storing data"

5. Could you please explain more about PoA? What is the role of "recall block"?

Thank you so much!


[26-May-18 05:18 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
@tierralibre 

We've actually just pushed a major update to the master version of Arweave, so make sure you have the most recent copy of the code!

Other than that, you can start mining by simply using the command:

./arweave-server mine

This should connect you to the main network and let you begin mining. In terms of posting data, I'd recommend using the web extension or the archiveit tools, though you may need to wait a few days for them to be updated to work with the new version of the source code.


[26-May-18 05:21 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
@Krypto Light 

1. The blockweave stores details of all transactions, and the list of hash values of previous blocks and active wallets

2. If you archived the file using Arweave, the data w2ould be stored in the blocks of the weave themselves

3. An even storage of the blockweave is maintained by financial pressure - the less widely mirrored a block is, the more financial profitable it is to store it

4. As the amount of data on the weave increases, the average number of miners mirroring each piece of data decreases. This means that the number of miners who have access to this data should it arise as a recall block is smaller, and equally, so is the amount of total hashing power contributed toward mining it. This means that, as the amount of data increases, so to does the amount of hashing per block decrease.

5. The role of the recall block is to provide an incentive for miners to store old data in the weave.

[02-Jun-18 12:17 AM] peitalin (Pe,P)#0935
Can anyone comment if blockshadow is similar to invertible bloom lookup tables?


[02-Jun-18 05:18 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Hi @Aliaksandr 
Check out our repository at https://github.com/arweaveteam/arweave, it should have some basic instructions to get you started in the readme. If you'd like more help, PM me.


[02-Jun-18 05:19 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
@peitalin (Pe,P) 
Blockshadows are a basically an invertible bloom lookup table of zero size. Instead of assuming that the number of differences in the two sets of transactions held by each node is small, arweave assumes it is zero. This is possible because Arweave nodes implement a delay before transactions are added to the pool to be mined, long enough that the assumption that each other node in the network is aware of all the transactions in my pool to be mined is highly certain.

{
    "id": "",     // base64url encoded random string of 32-bytes
    "last_tx": "",    // base64url encoded ID of last transaction made by address
    "owner": "",    // base64url encoded modulus of wallet making transaction
    "target": "",   // base64url encoded SHA256 hash of recipients modulus
    "quantity": "",   // string representing the amount of sent AR in winston
    "type": "",     // string stating type of transaction 'data' or 'transfer'
    "data": "",     // base64url encoded data being archived in transaction
    "reward": "",   // string representing the mining reward AR in winston
    "signature": ""   // base64url encoded signature of transaction
}

[01-Jul-18 06:01 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey bioharz,

One of our community admins just told me about your messages. The JSON storage of full block data is only temporary, don't worry. We will be moving to BSON or simiar for the local storage at some point. Regarding the wallet lists: As they are repeated across blocks they can be trivially compressed on the user's local machine. As miners in Arweave compete with thier ability to store data, finding the best compression algorithm is part of that competition. You would have read about this if you had waited for our mining email.

None of this data is actually transferred across the wire, of course. You can read about this in our lightpaper.

[01-Jul-18 06:13 AM] Scalefinity#7851
Can I delete the old blocks?


[01-Jul-18 06:13 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Yes


[01-Jul-18 06:14 AM] arweave-sam#9630
As many as you like (bar the last 50)


[01-Jul-18 06:14 AM] arweave-sam#9630
But you will spend less time hashing


[01-Jul-18 06:14 AM] arweave-sam#9630
This is because you use old blocks as 'tickets' for entry into the hashing competition for new blocks.


[01-Jul-18 06:14 AM] Scalefinity#7851
Hmm, I understand.


[01-Jul-18 06:15 AM] arweave-sam#9630
The more old blocks you store, the more hashing you take part in


[01-Jul-18 06:15 AM] arweave-sam#9630
This is Proof of Access -- details in the lightpaper


[01-Jul-18 06:16 AM] Scalefinity#7851
thx.
And whats about the enc folder in block folder?
encrypted blocks?
these blocked contain stored files on ar, right?


[01-Jul-18 06:18 AM] arweave-sam#9630
No, that is actually so that if you don't have the recall block, you can download it from your peers ahead of the distribution of the next block shadow, so that you can very quickly come to consensus about the next block


[01-Jul-18 06:20 AM] arweave-sam#9630
So if p1 doesn't have rb, but p2 does, p1 can ask for enc(rb) from p2, then when p2 finds the next block they can just distribute the decryption key in the block shadow, and p1 already has everything they need to verify the block.


[01-Jul-18 06:21 AM] arweave-sam#9630
This gives p1 all the time between bn and bn+1 to download that recall block, so that they are ready to verify bn+1 with just the 'shadow' of the new block.

[01-Jul-18 06:25 AM] arweave-sam#9630
I have removed them from the other channels. Let me know if you have any further questions.

That address should give you access to all the blocks and transactions.

[31-Oct-18 11:45 AM] beast#6522

[31-Oct-18 11:58 AM] beast#6522
@tiamat  are there any arch docs regarding persistence strategies  for large files


[31-Oct-18 11:59 AM] tiamat#9131
right now I guess the strategy for large files is to store in chunks and reassemble


[31-Oct-18 11:59 AM] tiamat#9131
Sam is here, so he will clarify  


[31-Oct-18 12:03 PM] arweave-sam#9630
There is technically a limit around 5mb right now, _but_ :

1. This is an implementation, not a protocol issue. We expect to be able to lift that limit.
2. There is an economic incentive for you not to store large chunks, but to break them up into smaller parts. Your second megabyte of storage (IIRC) will cost approximately 1.5-2x that of the first megabyte. We have attempted to construct an incentive here for the user to decide for themselves where/how to make the tradeoff, and to pay the network appropriately for the inconvenience. Smaller chunks take slightly longer to upload, are cheaper, and easier for the network to process, but larger/no chunking is easier for the client developer to build and upload is a bit faster.


[31-Oct-18 12:06 PM] tiamat#9131
considering the http protocol, paying more for large files sounds a good idea to me


[31-Oct-18 12:08 PM] beast#6522
yes and no, paying for the larger file also means that it is a single download stream for a browser,  so we cannot take advantage of the concurrent  request ability of the browsers, chrome for example can download 4 or 6 assets concurrently, this is why we break up our spa package if it increase  to multiple mb when minified into one file


[31-Oct-18 12:09 PM] beast#6522
im going to have to think about this one for a bit


[31-Oct-18 12:10 PM] beast#6522
@arweave-sam  thanks for the clarification.  do you have any docs besides the light paper and the http api docs?

[18-Nov-18 03:13 AM] tiamat#9131
The AR wallets use SHA256, is this right? Any reason for not starting with something stronger, like at least 384? Quantum computers are around the corner, why didn't you chose to be more prepared than other blockchains?


[19-Nov-18 12:22 PM] Marcin#0065
Ar is sha2 384


[19-Nov-18 02:07 PM] tiamat#9131
I'm talking about the wallets


[19-Nov-18 02:08 PM] tiamat#9131
not the miner


[20-Nov-18 10:48 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@tiamat  The wallet address is a SHA256 hash of the public key. To exploit this you must both exploit the RSA key generation together with SHA256. That’s very unlikely to suddenly happen.

In the past, hashing algos haven’t just suddenly become compromised. Warnings have been issued when weaknesses have been found years before anyone managed to exploit them. If weaknesses are found in SHA256, then we can switch to another algo.

Btw, the reason for hashing the public key is to have more convenient (i.e. shorter) wallet addresses. Using SHA384 would result in a longer wallet address.

Another really cool btw: Arweave doesn’t rely on any elliptic curve cryptography ✌️ like e.g. Bitcoin and Ethereum do. That’s a very strong advantage. Or rather, that’s an achilles heel of Bitcoin, Ethereum and most other blockchains.


[20-Nov-18 10:55 AM] arweave-martin#1169
Here is a table where you can see you how long time it took for several hashing algos going from being considered strong until they got compromised. http://valerieaurora.org/hash.html


[20-Nov-18 11:01 AM] arweave-sam#9630
 


[20-Nov-18 02:12 PM] tiamat#9131
@arweave-martin But the RSA key is not stored on the weave, so it does not matter, attacker only needs something with the same hash.


[20-Nov-18 02:19 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Yes, but the point is that if SHA-256 was broken, as well as finding a colliding hash the attacker would also need to find a valid RSA key pair that resulted in the collision. Changing any single bit of the RSA public key (which is used to produce the hash) would result in an invalid key pair, subsequently the search for a colliding hash is substantially more computationally complex.


[20-Nov-18 02:29 PM] tiamat#9131
ah, you are right, attacker would not only need a RSA key to match the hash, but also the pair


[21-Nov-18 07:51 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Yep -- would be tricky @tiamat 

The wallet list is also somewhat hash and length independent, so we should be able to easily support different algorithms, etc, in the future.

Hey @woombash, you can indeed install our web extension via Google Chrome, the same way you would with MetaMask. Once you have installed the extension, you have the option to create a new wallet or load an existing Arweave/Upvest wallet into there - It's currently only compatible with AR tokens. Once you're up and running, you can use the extension to archive web pages and send tokens between Arweave wallets. Here's a quick guide on how to get set up - https://medium.com/@arweave/introducing-the-arweave-web-extension-2-0-dd706d1c9523

[06-Jan-19 09:42 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@tierralibre Mix is using rebar3 for building, and rebar3 can build any Erlang app. Unfortunately, arweave is not an Erlang app but has a custom build system and other non standard things. Ergo, it's not registered as a running application in the VM.

Sooner or later we will have made arweave into an Erlang app and then you can add its git URL as a dependency to your mix project.

[06-Jan-19 09:48 AM] arweave-martin#1169
One idea for shortcut for making arweave an Erlang app is to create a bare-bone Erlang app called `arweave` which only do one thing and that's calling `ar:start/0` on startup. You don't even need to build the regular code with mix as long as you manually make sure to run the regular `make build` before starting your mix app.

[06-Jan-19 09:56 AM] arweave-martin#1169
Basically, if you run `make build` you will have all the compiled beam files in these 4 directories:
./ebin
./lib/prometheus/_build/default/lib/prometheus/ebin
./lib/accept/_build/default/lib/accept/ebin
./lib/prometheus_process_collector/_build/default/lib/prometheus_process_collector/ebin

If you just can add those directories to you path of the VM, then all modules will be available for use. See the `arweave-server` script to see how the paths are set (with the `-pa` argument)

```build: data blocks hash_lists wallet_lists
    ( \
        cd lib/jiffy && \
        ../../bin/mute-on-success ./rebar compile && \
        cd ../.. && \
        cp lib/jiffy/priv/jiffy.so ./priv/ \
    )
    (cd lib/prometheus && ./rebar3 compile)
    (cd lib/accept && ./rebar3 compile)
    ( \
        cd lib/prometheus_process_collector && \
        ./rebar3 compile && \
        cp _build/default/lib/prometheus_process_collector/priv/prometheus_process_collector.so ../../priv/ \
    )
    erlc $(ERLC_OPTS) +export_all -o ebin/ src/ar.erl
    erl $(ERL_OPTS) -noshell -s ar rebuild -s init stop```

[06-Jan-19 10:29 AM] tierralibre#2740
```mix compile.erlang View Source
Compiles Erlang source files.

When this task runs, it will first check the modification times of all files to be compiled and if they haven't been changed since the last compilation, it will not compile them. If any of them have changed, it compiles everything.

For this reason, the task touches your :compile_path directory and sets the modification time to the current time and date at the end of each compilation. You can force compilation regardless of modification times by passing the --force option.

 Command line options
--force - forces compilation regardless of modification times

--all-warnings - prints warnings even from files that do not need to be recompiled

 Configuration
ERL_COMPILER_OPTIONS - can be used to give default compile options. The value must be a valid Erlang term. If the value is a list, it will be used as is. If it is not a list, it will be put into a list.

:erlc_paths - directories to find source files. Defaults to ["src"].

:erlc_include_path - directory for adding include files. Defaults to "include".

:erlc_options - compilation options that apply to Erlang's compiler. Defaults to [:debug_info].

For a complete list of options, see :compile.file/2.

For example, to configure the erlc_options for your Erlang project you may run:

erlc_options: [:debug_info, {:i, 'path/to/include'}]```

[06-Jan-19 10:35 AM] tierralibre#2740
```defmodule Sauspiel.Mixfile do
  use Mix.Project

  def project do
    [elixir: "0.14.3",
     apps_path: "apps",
     compile_path: ".",
     default_task: "compile",
     deps: deps]
  end

  def subproject_defaults do
    Dict.merge [
      elixir: project[:elixir],
      compilers: [:copyapp, :erlang],
      default_task: "compile",
      erlc_options: erlc_options,
      deps: deps,
      deps_path: "../../deps",
      lockfile: "../../mix.lock",
      compile_path: ".",
    ], subproject_defaults(Mix.env)
  end

  defp subproject_defaults(:test), do: [
    # Compile tests and -IFDEF'ed parts of source files
    erlc_paths: ["src", "test"],
    erlc_options: [{:d, :TEST}] ++ erlc_options
  ]
  defp subproject_defaults(_), do: []

  defp erlc_options do
    # Using Mix.Project.compile_path here raises an exception,
    # use Mix.Project.config[:compile_path] instead.
    root_path = Path.expand("../..", Mix.Project.config[:compile_path])
    includes = Path.wildcard(Path.join(root_path, "apps/*/include"))
    [:debug_info] ++ Enum.map(includes, fn(path) -> {:i, path} end)
  end

  defp, deps do: [] # you know what goes here
end

defmodule Mix.Tasks.Compile.Copyapp do
  use Mix.Task

  def run(_) do
    project      = Mix.Project.config
    source_paths = project[:erlc_paths]
    compile_path = Mix.Project.compile_path
    files        = Mix.Utils.extract_files(source_paths, "*.app.src")

    File.mkdir_p!(compile_path)
    Enum.each(files, fn(app_src_file) ->
      app_file = Path.join(compile_path, Path.basename(app_src_file, ".src"))
      File.copy!(app_src_file, app_file)
    end)
  end
end```

[11-Feb-19 03:43 AM] arweave-sophie#4476

[11-Feb-19 04:28 AM] Goldberg | StakeSquid#5271
@arweave-sophie I can't find anything about ArQL, ... do you have a link?


[11-Feb-19 04:36 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Hey @Goldberg | StakeSquid we're working on docs for these features but the tl;dr version is you can send a HTTP POST request to the `/arql` endpoint on a node and it'll give you transactions that match a given tag


[11-Feb-19 04:37 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
For example:

`POST arweave.net/arql`
```json
{
    "op": "equals", 
    "expr1": "User-Agent",
    "expr2": "ArweaveChrome/2.0.3"
}
```
That will find txs that have the value `ArweaveChrome/2.0.3` on their `User-Agent` tag


[11-Feb-19 04:39 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Expressions can be nested and you can apply boolean logic, so for example if i wanted to find transactions from `ArweaveChrome/2.0.2` or `ArweaveChrome/2.0.3` I could do this

`POST arweave.net/arql`
```json
{
    "op": "or",
    "expr1": {
        "op": "equals",
        "expr1": "User-Agent",
        "expr2": "ArweaveChrome/2.0.3"
    },
    "expr2": {
        "op": "equals",
        "expr1": "User-Agent",
        "expr2": "ArweaveChrome/2.0.2"
    }
}
```


[11-Feb-19 04:40 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
You could nest expressions further and mix ands/ors to run some interesting queries and find matching txs


[11-Feb-19 04:42 AM] arweave-kyle#4569

https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/358038065974870018/544468373203976202/tx-tags.png

[11-Feb-19 04:43 AM] arweave-kyle#4569

[03-Apr-19 08:20 AM] christopher#3717
Few questions based that were not entirely clear from reading the whitepaper.


[03-Apr-19 08:20 AM] christopher#3717
1. Arweave seems to incentivize max redundancy through randomly selecting recall blocks. 
Wouldn’t that mean that it is in a miners interest to simply store everything they can and purchase harddisks? Other decentralized storage systems all use a sharding approach, where number of replicas can be controlled.
How does the project solve the most basic problem that all nodes need to store all information?


[03-Apr-19 08:21 AM] christopher#3717
2. How do you ensure, that recall blocks never get lost and that replication for all blocks is somewhat equal in the network? There is no explicit mechanism for this as far as I see. How likely is it, that a block could get lost with standard miner behaviour (which is likely storing random blocks)? Shouldn’t there be a more advanced mechanism to guarantee true permanence that considers the number of replica?


[03-Apr-19 09:06 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey @christopher 

1: Arweave is a proof of work network which creates a competition for storage capacity, as well as hashing power. It does indeed create a situation in which miners are incentivised to make copies of as many recall blocks as they can store -- this is by design -- although it does not _require_ them to store all of the data. Fundamentally this is an incentive based approach rather than a contractual approach. This maximises redundant copies for the storers in the network, lowering the probability of data loss (see below), as well as decreasing the latency for finding data (more redundant copies means that a user is more likely to find the data faster).
2: I actually have a draft blog post on this that I have been meaning to post for a while. It goes into all of the statistics regarding block availability as well as a comparison with redundancy-limited contractual approaches to decentralised storage.


[03-Apr-19 09:06 AM] arweave-sam#9630

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/358038065974870018/563001309490577408/ContractsVsIncentives-Statistics-DRAFT.rtf


[03-Apr-19 09:08 AM] christopher#3717
Thank you. Few more:


[03-Apr-19 09:10 AM] christopher#3717
3. Wildfire is supposed to incentivize data provisioning to interested parties. However, these seem to only ever be miners. Wasn’t the purpose to serve data through a REST-API to anyone? This would not be part of the record.
4. Blockshadowing makes sense, but only works for miners, who do collect TX information before a block is mined. Furthermore, recall blocks can not be expected to be widely available and will always have to be sent. Is there any approach to address this?
5. Blacklist is a simple local file filter. Little protection and a lot of responsibility for the user. How are these blacklists shared?
6. There seems to be a tradeoff between storing recall blocks and being fast in calculating PoW. How is difficulty adjusted? How do you address ASICs?


[03-Apr-19 09:30 AM] tiamat#9131
6. I think they should be like a milestones, when ASICs jump in, it means the project is well known, important and well incentivized  


[03-Apr-19 10:12 AM] Vilenarios#8742
Professional questions here guys. Looking forward to the answers.


[03-Apr-19 11:04 AM] arweave-sam#9630
3: WF does indeed work between miners (who communicate amongst themselves through the RESTful API you mention), or things that _look_ like miners. This means that you can always be sure to get your data from other nodes if you run a local node on your machine (by comparison, running local node software is always required to get your data from the network in Filecoin, Sia etc). But you can also get your data from nodes that cannot distinguish you from other nodes (by User-Agent header spoofing, etc), or simply from altruistic nodes that do not care (similarly to the distribution of old blocks in Bitcoin, ETH, and over-seeding in Bittorrent). Attempting to disguise browsers as nodes will inevitably lead to a cat and mouse game, so while functional, we are looking at various mechanisms of incentivising gateways to share traffic with non-participating 'visitor' users.
4. Miners only store transactions that they can mine into blocks. This makes them potentially valuable to the node in question. Optionally, nodes can choose to serve data from transactions that are pending but by default this is not enabled. After the `fast-write` network upgrade recall block distribution won't be required at all (succinct proofs of access will instead be distributed with the block shadow itself).


[03-Apr-19 11:04 AM] arweave-sam#9630
5. We expect that miners will eventually organise communities around the maintenance of these content policies in a similar way to the maintenance systems of adblocking lists on the centralised web. In terms of sharing, at the basic level we expect these to be distributed through web downloads, however it would be great if a community member made a 'subscribe to wallet' `adt_app` that loads new policy lists when a wallet distributes them in a new signed transaction. In the short term, we are also talking to the Internet Watch Foundation ( https://www.iwf.org.uk ) to get miners access to their lists, but these conversations are currently on-going.
6. Yes, storage vs hashing expenditure by miners is a tradeoff. Given the low cost of storage and the relatively high cost of energy expenditure and hashing hardware, miners are incentivised to optimise for GB-capacity before H/s. In terms of ASIC resistance: we have been running a progwork testnet for Arweave since early December. We are approaching this cautiously (for obvious reasons), but we expect to ship it in the mid-term (likely before v 2.0).

 
https://www.iwf.org.uk

[03-Apr-19 12:40 PM] tiamat#9131
Could you tell more about progwork? Will it include proof of capacity or just different PoW for ASIC resistance ?


[03-Apr-19 01:01 PM] arweave-sam#9630
As it currently stands it is just a programmatic POW, but adding a proof of (unused) hard disk capacity component would be nice. The complexity would emerge from carefully calculating the right trade-offs between proof of access, proof of work, and proof of capacity together. In particular, we would have to be careful not to introduce an incentive to favour proving empty hard drive capacity over proof of access to useful data.


[03-Apr-19 01:01 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Workable, but we haven't looked at that combination together in enough depth yet


[03-Apr-19 01:15 PM] arweave-sam#9630
For an intro to programmatic PoWs in general, this sets a good background: https://blog.sia.tech/the-state-of-cryptocurrency-mining-538004a37f9b

> At the end of the day, you will always be able to create custom hardware that can outperform general purpose hardware. 

...but it is what this statement _misses_ that gives birth to the potential for programmatic PoWs. Yes, you will always be able to create custom hardware that outperforms general purpose hardware _for specific tasks_. Progwork (and other projects like it) turn the task itself into general purpose computation -- the exact task that typical CPUs are optimised to perform well.

 
https://blog.sia.tech/the-state-of-cryptocurrency-mining-538004a37f9b
The State of Cryptocurrency Mining
For those new to the blog, I am the lead developer of Sia, a blockchain based cloud storage platform. About a year ago, myself and some…
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/gl4GzBTQ4MlZd32kJQjMWEmmcGQulLHfYU8bQ3o4msQ/https/cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1200/1%2AzS5JJg6O8ui-YPmg1YyUlg.jpeg


[03-Apr-19 01:18 PM] arweave-sam#9630
In the basic case this class of algorithms (ours included) follows the formula of hashing the input, seeding a PRNG with that hash, generating a random program and a random virtual machine CPU state, executing the VM for some  large number of instructions, then collecting the CPU state and hashing that again.


[03-Apr-19 01:20 PM] arweave-sam#9630
The hashes (of course) and the PRNG can be optimised with specialised hardware, so the number of instructions to run of the VM should be sufficient that this optimisation is not worth it.

[02-May-19 02:17 PM] arweave-sam#9630
We have our own version, but we are also looking at potentially using RandomX

[04-May-19 02:58 PM] arweave-sam#9630
@Paste Connoisseur Not right now, but you can start your own local network if you like


[04-May-19 02:59 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Setting up the mining software, then running `./arweave-server init mine` should work


[04-May-19 02:59 PM] arweave-sam#9630
@tiamat Yes, it is on the roadmap for after the next forking release


[04-May-19 03:14 PM] tiamat#9131
what is the fork addressing ? content filter or multiple txs/wallet/block?


[04-May-19 03:19 PM] arweave-sam#9630
`faster-write` we are calling it internally. It has multiple txs/wallet/block and higher max TX chunk sizes


[04-May-19 03:19 PM] arweave-sam#9630
The updated content policies will also be shipped with/before it


[04-May-19 03:20 PM] arweave-sam#9630
After the initial `faster-write` fork, we are expecting to release another update that allows miners to 'vote' on max TX chunk size by allowing miners to increase or decrease it slightly in every new block


[04-May-19 03:22 PM] arweave-sam#9630
After `faster-write`, the next _major_ project will be `fast-write` (these names will need changing   ), which uses `SPOAs` to avoid having to write the full data into the chain itself, while still preserving the perpetual incentive to be able to recall the whole data


[04-May-19 03:24 PM] arweave-sam#9630
This will be a fairly big architecture change, so it will take us quite a lot longer to ship. But after that you should be able to write data into the network at extremely high rates.

[05-May-19 07:07 AM] arweave-lev#3466
Hi @Lyner, nice idea! Yes, you can use a destination address for that. Alternatively, you could come up with a tag and collect all transactions with this tag.

Some examples from our Weavemail app. Here we assign tags to emails - https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/weavemail/blob/master/compose.js#L42. Here we fetch emails both by tags and the destination address - https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/weavemail/blob/master/inbox.js#L5.

[12-May-19 05:09 PM] arweave-sam#9630

[12-May-19 05:09 PM] benji#5402

[12-May-19 05:09 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Mined into a block


[12-May-19 05:09 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Returning `200` on the `/tx/[id]/status` endpoint


[12-May-19 05:10 PM] benji#5402
Why is it necessary to wait ?


[12-May-19 05:12 PM] arweave-sam#9630
You need to make sure that the `last_tx` value for the second TX is correct, and that the first TX _definitely_ arrives before the second


[12-May-19 05:12 PM] benji#5402
Ahhhh ok, that's a headache.


[12-May-19 05:13 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Yeah, it is so that a malicious attacker cannot send a bunch of transactions that can never be mined and have them cached in the mempool for too long


[12-May-19 05:13 PM] arweave-sam#9630
As our transactions are big, it is more important than for other networks


[12-May-19 05:15 PM] arweave-sam#9630
But we should have the next version out in the next month or so, that allows you to 'spray' as many TXs as you like at the network, and as long as the valid 'chain' appears within a reasonable period, it works

[12-May-19 06:58 PM] 2072 [ANFRA]#9291
Hi, are there any plans to improve the blockchain storage size/effectiveness in the near future?

[12-May-19 07:14 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey @2072 [ANFRA] !


[12-May-19 07:16 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Yes, we plan to move from a wallet list system an append only wallet log, which will greatly cut down the overhead in the hard fork after next (2 major releases away).


[12-May-19 07:16 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Because it uses a blockweave though, you don't need to store all of it


[12-May-19 07:17 PM] arweave-sam#9630
You just get rewarded for the proportion of the weave that you do store.


[12-May-19 07:18 PM] arweave-sam#9630
So if you are filled to capacity now, you will be able to keep mining most of blocks for the next month, then > 50% for the first year, etc.

[15-May-19 12:57 AM] tiamat#9131
@arweave-sam what's wrong with JSON?


[15-May-19 12:57 AM] tiamat#9131
why some nodes have 400+ peers?


[15-May-19 03:47 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@tiamat JSON is relatively big so consumes bandwidth when traveling over the wire and storage when put on disk. Also it is relatively slow to parse. We have to keep backwards-compatibility with JSON in the API cause it's very convenient to have it there but we can introduce a different serialisation format to improve the rest.

Which nodes are you referring to?


[15-May-19 04:26 AM] tiamat#9131
@arweave-lev 139.59.51.59:1984 425 peers


[15-May-19 05:04 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@tiamat That's one of our own nodes. It's probably behind a load balancer so that it gets web traffic. The node cannot distinguish between a request from a web browser and from another node, so web browsers' IP addresses will be in the peer list for a while.

hey @aurora   in fact you can use the permaweb as a db or to get data from it externally, and you can also only have a permaweb site and interact with external APIs, but just keep in mind that your permaweb is permanent, while an external API isn't, it will change for sure at one point

[22-May-19 02:20 PM] JustMaier#0425
@arweave-sam would that be the same as setting up a miner?


[22-May-19 03:37 PM] arweave-lev#3466
@JustMaier you need to change the minimal difficulty to something small (say, 16); the default one would be too hard for a single machine so it won't produce blocks. https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/master/src/ar.hrl#L54

And then running `./arweave-server init mine` should do it. You can access it on `localhost:1984`.

 
https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/master/src/ar.hrl

[26-May-19 04:39 AM] arweave-sam#9630
@JustMaier the owner field is the base64url encoded public key of the submitter


[26-May-19 04:40 AM] arweave-sam#9630
If you decode, then hash (sha2-256), then encode in b64u again, you get the address :)


[26-May-19 04:40 AM] arweave-sam#9630
The inbox page on weavemail does this


[26-May-19 09:58 AM] JustMaier#0425

[26-May-19 10:15 AM] arweave-sam#9630
No real 'ceremony'


[26-May-19 10:15 AM] arweave-sam#9630
You need the public key so that you can verify that the transaction was signed by the right account

[27-May-19 02:01 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@JustMaier @Paste Connoisseur unfortunately you can only submit one tx per block from a single wallet at the moment. The second one has to be submitted after the first is included into the block. We are working on adding support for submitting multiple transactions per wallet per block.

{Reactions}
😩 (2)  

[27-May-19 02:03 AM] arweave-sam#9630
You can actually get multiple txs per wallet per block now, but you need to manually adjust the `last_tx` value and be _absolutely sure_ that the first transaction has been distributed to every node before the second one.


[27-May-19 02:04 AM] arweave-sam#9630
This second condition is normally extremely difficult to achieve, particularly for larger data transactions


[27-May-19 02:04 AM] arweave-sam#9630
But as Lev said, an upcoming patch will remove this issue.


[27-May-19 02:08 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@arweave-sam no I do not think it's possible, `last_tx` is only looked for among the transactions already included into the blocks (put into the wallet list, to be precise, and it's not put until the block is processed).


[27-May-19 02:10 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Nope, Upvest have been doing this in production since last June

[16-Sep-17 06:49 PM] Kumi#0610
I see you were talking about bots and welcoming messages earlier. I would advice you not to switch to a bot which PMs new users, they are not appreciated. What most large servers do these days is automatically assign all new users a special role which gives them access to only the welcome channel. Upon joining they are mentioned in a message giving them all the information a new user needs. After the user has read the message they type the, by the bot, given phrase and their role is changed to one which has access to all other channels but not the welcoming one.


[16-Sep-17 07:03 PM] Dann#7704
@Kumi Interesting, thank you for the advice - why are they not appreciated? I would imagine having to manually type a command in would be more time consuming than just jumping on and getting involved immediately.


[16-Sep-17 07:07 PM] Kumi#0610
They aren't appreciated primarily because people would rather get pinged in the relevant server and partly because it's usually the same bot which sends the message, though it's for different servers, so it all gets mixed in the same place. The reason a lot of servers have it so that new users have to type a command is just to make sure they read the message, perhaps that is not something you are interested in.


[16-Sep-17 07:10 PM] Dann#7704
It would entirely depend on the demographic and how they interact with the platform. I can appreciate the interaction a user would receive from having to enter a command as to show that they understand the concepts.


[16-Sep-17 07:11 PM] Dann#7704
Albeit it may put some people off, but it's interesting to get that feedback as it's not something that may be obvious.


[16-Sep-17 07:12 PM] karthik#8506
It will be better than no one answering for 12-15 hrs


[16-Sep-17 07:16 PM] Kumi#0610
Indeed it would. My experience is primarily from servers quite unlike this one, so it's entirely possible that the sentiment will be different here. Mee is a widely used bot despite that many dislike it simply because the server admins find it an elegant solution.


[16-Sep-17 07:20 PM] Dann#7704

[27-Sep-17 09:08 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Indeed, @Puck342. We are actually considering releasing 'Archain core' (permanent data storage network, not the internet archiving layer) potentially even earlier than expected (although we certainly can't make any promises about that yet).  While this would mean that the community could get started with the data storage technology, apps and theirs wallets earlier, we are hesitant to do this because we don't want it to be misinterpreted as a move away from our commitment to the Archain internet archiving system. This still remainins absolutely vital to Archain, it is simply that the software is split into distinct layers that could feasibly be delivered seperately. The internet archiving relies on the core, so that is the first part we are focussing on.

Conceivably, I could see that some people that aren't following the project too closely would see this as a re-definition of the product, which would be a great shame, as it is simply that the product is deliverable in stages. I would love to hear the thoughts of the community about this, if they have any?

(Once again, we can't make any promises about the early release of archain-core, yet, please understand that this is currently just at the ideas stage.)


[27-Sep-17 11:06 AM] Puck342#3354

[31-Oct-17 07:40 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Thanks for all the feedback guys, it's super helpful.

Yeah, to clarify, this is simply a renaming of the currency part of Archain, we just wanted to make sure the currency has it's own identity -- archive cash to go with the archiving chain. Over the long and very-long term, though, we wanted to highlight the association between the data archived on the weave, and the tokens.

We're still exactly as committed to the ideals of our project as before. We're not changing anything about how Archain will work or what we want to achieve.

Regarding the website: we're looking to update it a little, but it will still very much be the archain project. Both domains will point to the homepage of the Archain project, we just prefer ar.cash due to length/snappiness.

All the best,
Sam + Will

[31-Oct-17 01:01 PM] arweave-sam#9630
That is how we see it, too, @operater.

ar.cash is just the name of the token, which needed to change from ARC due to naming collisions with other projects. While we agree on the direction of cash in society, we think that it is still a better word than 'token'. We also expect that it's semantic meaning will change over time -- in the same way that 'directory' now refers to a computing concept, rather than its initial 'real-world' meaning.

It seems that most of the issue here is based around the move of the homepage from archain.org to ar.cash. While we cannot make a decision about that immediately, we have certainly taken these thoughts on-board.

[21-Dec-17 03:08 AM] Marcin#0065
General question to mining: is archain mining sha-256 or scrypt-mining? Or maybe something different? I have some old usb miner (antminer used for bitcoin long time ago) and was wondering, if i bring them back to life to use them for archain.


[21-Dec-17 07:12 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Archain currently uses sha256, but we are considering some alternatives, too.


[21-Dec-17 07:14 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We will confirm the hashing alg for the PoW long before main net launch though, to make sure people have time to prepare their mining setups.


[21-Dec-17 11:58 AM] Marcin#0065
scrypt mining would be awesome, a lot scrypt miners are around with better efficeny  


[23-Dec-17 06:44 AM] arweave-sam#9630
One of the main considerations regarding hashing algorithm choice is whether the specialised hardware for it is concentrated in a single geographic location. For example, IIRC ~80% of the world's sha-256 specialised mining hardware is found in China. For a project like ours, one country having >50% of the hashing power should be avoided if at all possible.

Another concern is longevity. We want the Archain (in its current form) to run for potentially hundreds of years. While that means that the hashing algorithm will very likely be broken and have to be replaced at some point, we want to go as long as we can before that becomes necessary.

One of the options we have been looking at is the Cuckoo Cycle algorithm. CC is bottlenecked by memory bandwidth (rather than computation), making it extremely difficult for one country to gain a monopoly over the 'means of consensus'. It is also based on finding cycles in directed graphs, which has been extremely well studied (making breaks in the algorithm unlikely for a while).

A side note about the Cuckoo Cycle is that it would allow non-trivial amounts of mining to be done on phones, laptops, and other low energy devices.

That is where we are internally regarding hashing algortihms. Comments always welcome :-).


[23-Dec-17 07:08 AM] Marcin#0065
Sounds really nice   i believe you will choose the best choice for your project. I didnt know china was that big in mining  


[23-Dec-17 07:11 AM] Marcin#0065

[16-Jan-18 10:17 AM] arweave-india#5075
Hi all

Thanks @BBM and @Marcin#0065 for contributing - you guys are indeed correct (as usual! :D) - SHA-256 is being used for the test network. For the main network, we're exploring some interesting options for the Proof of Work component of the Proof of Access algorithm that would be memory-bound (ensuring a good geographic distribution of computing power)  and also involve constant re-verification of data in the network. It's important to stress though that these algorithms would be nested inside the wider Proof of Access system, so are not as integral as they are in other cryptocurrency systems. 

@cromulon  - the total supply of tokens is 55mil in the Genesis block, and I believe your other queries have been addressed here too, answered here by other very kind users! Let me know if there's anything else you're curious about.

@Soros | RealSatoshi - The total during the pre-sale we raised approximately $550k USD.

As always guys let me know any and all of your questions and comments, I'm always happy to help and chat

[12-Feb-18 10:10 PM] NQ#1049
Hey I have  afew Qs :)

Do we have a working product? 
What's our closest competitors? 

Are we similar to Substratum/Orchid Protocol ?


[12-Feb-18 10:10 PM] NQ#1049
If so, wht differentiates us :)


[13-Feb-18 04:16 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Hey @NQ


[13-Feb-18 04:17 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Yes! We're currently running a stable backer test network. Currently the test net is only availible to backers, but the next major version will be public.


[13-Feb-18 04:19 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Our closest competition is probably NXT, who are doing a very similar thing but without changing the blockchain data structure


[13-Feb-18 04:21 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
This forces them to limit TXs to 42kb each because they're stuck with all of the native blockchain scaling problems,something that isn't a problem to us


[13-Feb-18 04:22 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Substratum and Orchid are both super interesting projects for tacking internet freedom, but they come at the problem very differently to us


[13-Feb-18 04:24 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
The main difference comes once again from the scaling problems that limit them but not us


[13-Feb-18 04:25 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Our main differentiation is that we store all our content on chain


[13-Feb-18 04:25 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
This means users pay once, and can recall the data itself from the chain, forever


[13-Feb-18 04:26 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Orchid and Substratum however, are basically payment settlement layers for internet related services


[13-Feb-18 04:27 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Hope this helps!

[26-Feb-18 03:05 AM] arweave-sam#9630
@bruce the Arweave is similar to NXT in that it stores information permanently on the data structure itself (unlike Filecoin, etc). It is unlike NXT in terms of the underlying technology, a blockweave not a blockchain, which frees it from the transactions size and scalability limits experienced by NXT.

[04-Mar-18 11:23 AM] Pancake#8004
How does ARWeave compare to IPFS

[04-Mar-18 11:28 AM] Pancake#8004
Filecoin


[04-Mar-18 02:22 PM] HiteshB#8784

[04-Mar-18 04:29 PM] lungov#3562
 


[05-Mar-18 06:52 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
hi @Pancake


[05-Mar-18 06:52 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
IPFS/Filecoin are part of a family of storage blockchains that rely on proofs of retrievability, specifically they make use of a challenge/response protocol to ensure that a third party is holding the data and only ever store these proofs on the chain - not the data itself. Factom also does something similar, but on the bitcoin network - and instead of using proofs of retrieviability it just pushes periodic message digests.

Arweave on the other hand, stores data on the chain. We can do this because the blockweave data structure lets our the chain can be spread across many computers. This lets us maintain firm guarentees about the datas validity, etc that other projects can't make.

Hope this answers the question! Always here if you've got anymore


[05-Mar-18 07:00 AM] Pancake#8004
@WillRogerJones What's the advantages on keeping it on-chain as opposed to storing proofs of tretrievability?


[05-Mar-18 07:53 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
@Pancake The advantage of storing on chain is that the data becomes part of the proof of work going forward. This means two things: you pay once, and store forever, and that storage really is forever in archains case.


[05-Mar-18 07:54 AM] Pancake#8004
I see, because in ARweave, the miners are constantly being rewarded as part of the mining process for storage


[05-Mar-18 07:54 AM] Pancake#8004
Is there ongoing cost with IPFS/Filcoin and Factom? Does someone need to pay an monthly fee?


[05-Mar-18 07:56 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Yeah, thats exactly the case with IPFS/Filecoin


[05-Mar-18 07:56 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
If I remember correctly, you basically assign a number of blocks the data has to be stored for in filecoin, and are charged based on this


[05-Mar-18 07:59 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
I'm a little less familiar with Factom, but I believe that they don't charge based on time held


[05-Mar-18 07:59 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
but since they are piggybacking on the btc network, the amount of data that they can store at any given point is tiny - they're restirced to something like one hash every 10 minutes


[05-Mar-18 08:29 AM] Pancake#8004
Hmm... okay


[05-Mar-18 08:29 AM] Pancake#8004
Makes sense! Thanks

[07-Mar-18 05:46 AM] 真善狠得自由>#5484
How to set key file in ATN.1?


[07-Mar-18 06:02 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Hi @真善狠得自由> 

There are a few ways you can set your atn1 keyfile. If you don't have a key, but want one, you can set the new mining key flag when starting the server by adding the new_mining_key option and the server will generate you one. If you have the keyfile you want to load, you can use the 'load_mining_key' option, and provide the filepath to the key. Also, if you have the public key of the address you want to load, you can use the mining_addr option, and provide the public key.

For Example, to load the key "mykey.json":
./archain-server mine load_mining_key mykey.json


[07-Mar-18 06:05 AM] 真善狠得自由>#5484
I have the public key in the pre-sale


[07-Mar-18 06:07 AM] 真善狠得自由>#5484
what is a valid Archain network key file?


[07-Mar-18 06:16 AM] arweave-sam#9630
The test network uses a different set of keys than the main network (in order to keep real keys secure during the testing phase). To gain a key file for use on the test network you can either generate a new one with the new_mining_key flag, or visit your order page to generate a test net key for a wallet (with your normal balance) that will be added next time the network resets. If you can't find your order page, please send an email to 'team@arweave.org' and we will help you out.

[16-Mar-18 10:22 AM] Pancake#8004
If I were to host a website and use ARweave as my database and I would like to make edits to said website, would every revision to a file cost the same as uploading the file itself?


[16-Mar-18 10:33 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Depending on the size of the data it might be more efficient to publish a 'diff' of the updates to the file onto the weave, with a pointer back to the previous version. These 'modification' transactions allow you only to pay for the data you have altered, without affecting the underlying permanence and traceability of the system.


[16-Mar-18 10:50 AM] Pancake#8004
When fetching the data from the weave, is the performance affected if there are 10000+ diffs and each are stored in blocks that are in different nodes?


[16-Mar-18 11:05 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Yes, you would want to publish a new full version every so often, depending on the size of the original file.


[16-Mar-18 11:11 AM] Pancake#8004
Makes sense!
