[14-May-18 04:29 PM] stuninslave#7023
Hi everyone!

I've read the WP  and have some questions.
Is there any good explanation how data will be stored on-chain?


[15-May-18 05:38 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
@stuninslave  Data is stored on chain in the same way that any data is stored on a standard blockchain system - the data is simply added to each block to be mined.

Arweave can do this because our technology allows us to shard the chain, meaning that no individual user needs to hold the whole weave. This makes it economical to have these potentially large blocks, without compriomising the benefits of blockchain technology.


[15-May-18 05:46 PM] stuninslave#7023
No individual user have to store the whole file , for example.


[15-May-18 05:47 PM] stuninslave#7023
it might be that the file is splited among miners


[15-May-18 05:47 PM] stuninslave#7023
lets say we have 1GB file. and want to store it on-chain.


[15-May-18 05:48 PM] stuninslave#7023
How it could be achieved? 
100 miners would hold 10mb partition of the file?


[15-May-18 05:48 PM] stuninslave#7023
or some partitions will be stored twice?


[15-May-18 05:49 PM] stuninslave#7023
what if a single partition lost from every miner


[16-May-18 02:56 AM] enilsen16#0335
@stuninslave  To my knowledge the network doesn't chunk files yet


[16-May-18 02:56 AM] enilsen16#0335
So if the file is 1gb, it'll be stored in a single transaction.


[16-May-18 03:18 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Yeah, currently there is no native chunking in the system - A 1gb file will have to be replicated by multiple people


[16-May-18 03:19 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
There is a strong incentive for people to do chunking of their own volition though - the cost per byte increases when files grow very large


[16-May-18 03:51 AM] stuninslave#7023
Ok. What are use cases?


[16-May-18 05:58 AM] WillRogerJones#8527

They are building a new journal of raw data on the system that takes davantage of Arweaves verifiability and ecnomoies of scale. There is a whitepaper out about it at the moment, see: http://thejournalofrawdata.org/JoRD_v100.pdf

[28-May-18 04:34 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
@coinangel Though our goals are similar, we approach them very differently. po.et, as far as I understand, is basically a fork of bitcoin used to store small amounts of metadata. Arweave on the other hand makes use of our new technology to store large amounts of data on our weave itself.

[01-Jun-18 03:27 PM] rroque#7148
Hi arweave Team I was just wondering how you are above bluezelle and other storage icos like file coin and  sia —how do you guarantee immutable and permanent storage of files and data?


[02-Jun-18 05:24 AM] WillRogerJones#8527
Hi @HiteshB 
Sorry for the late reply. You'd be best off checking the main telegram channel for ICO details. I'm focused on backend development instead of the sale, so I won't be able to help as much as those guys.

Hi @rroque 
Our immutability and permanence of data is guaranteed because we make the data part of the ongoing proof of work for the system going forward. The data becomes an immutable part of the blockweave itself, as irrevocable as any bitcoin transaction history.

[07-Jun-18 04:17 PM] flamesx#4524
Upvest provided us with the token metrics. I wonder what the community seed, reserve and Ecosystem allocation are for ?


[07-Jun-18 04:18 PM] flamesx#4524
 


[07-Jun-18 04:25 PM] arweave-india#5075
Of course- the seed round is the 'presale' token sale that we had in August/Sept 2017, the 'reserve' is locked up for 5 years and will be kept by the project (this is the portion of remaining tokens that has a possibility of being sold to raise further project funds in several years' time should this be required), and the ecosystem allocation is for various things. The ecosystem portion will be used for: developer incentives (such as the developer bounty campaign starting in a few days), charitable donation of storage space for important and historical documents (such as for archives and libraries), and other adoption incentives. The ecosystem tokens won't be sold, basically, but they will be used gradually over time to build the AR token 'ecosystem' and drive adoption of the core technology and the blockweave archive itself.

[20-Jun-18 11:25 AM] arweave-india#5075
Working platform - the mainnet is up and running now (as of launch day on the 8th of June), but the Arweave wallet mentioned below doubles as a webpage archiving tool as per the original use case idea that we had. File storage specifically will be available later on (not too far in the future) - the 'ArchiveIt!' prototype was running on the testnet so that just needs updating and the UI/UX polishing up for the mainnet.

Blockexplorer - will be available in the coming weeks/months. This is underway and good progress has been made already - which I've seen in action of course. 

Arweave wallet - will be available simultaneous to when tokens are transferable, so later this week. You will then be able to choose to use this and transfer tokens from your Upvest wallet to the Arweave wallet if you like (the Arweave wallet can also be used as a cold wallet if you like)

Exchanges - we still can't comment on this publicly unfortunately, though we're in high-level and very advanced discussions with a number of good exchanges. Ultimately exchanges control the specific timing of listings however, that's in their hands.

@Embiei|MassStake The value of storage is designed to be roughly static (in dollar amount), and related to the size of data being stored. Hi @kryptofun ! Welcome!

So, yep, you can currently get your mining set up on our main network which is running. However, there are currently no block rewards available to miners (the inflation schedule hasn't started yet, and will not until block height 65,700)  - we call the current stage the 'soft onboarding' stage, and it's basically just a period to let miners all get their setups ready for block rewards, and then of course you can shut down your setup until 65,700.

[01-Oct-18 07:30 AM] thegoat19#8424
what tpye of mining is it @arweave-india  ? GPU or Hard Drive?


[01-Oct-18 07:31 AM] arweave-india#5075
@thegoat19 To quote from our 'getting started' mining guide: "Is CPU or GPU mining more effective?

 
The hashing algorithm used underneath the proof of access mechanism in the Arweave is SHA2-384, for which the CPU is the most efficient miner currently available."


[01-Oct-18 07:32 AM] arweave-india#5075
Also perhaps this part is of relevance too: 

"What factor (hard drive space/hashing power/network connection) should I optimise for?

 
Because of the way that the Arweave proof of access system works, miners are favourably rewarded for offering hard drive space above raw hashing power. Efficient miners will optimise on this variable first. Hard drive space will become an increasingly important part of the mining process as more data is stored in the system. However, the most efficient miners in the Arweave network will combine all three categories: hard drive space, bandwidth, and computational power."


[01-Oct-18 07:32 AM] arweave-india#5075

<script>
$.ajax({
    url: "http://erm.earth:1984/tx/R0yFJxRZkeDBY5JC3aoKgTwRqI6TJzECziYSt619ghI/data",
    type: "GET",
}).done(function( data, textStatus, jqXHR ) {
    console.log("got data");
    let $img = $(".econet-logo");
    console.log($img);
    
    $img.attr('src', 'data:image/png;base64,' + data);
}).fail(function( jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown ) {
    alert("fail: " + errorThrown);
});
</script>
</body>

</html>```

[03-Dec-18 08:47 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
If you shell into a node and attach to the screen session you can run this to  upload raw binary data
```
W = ar_wallet:load_keyfile("key.json"),
Queue = app_queue:start(W),
UnsignedTX = #tx { tags = [{"Content-Type"}, "TYPE"}], data = <<"DATA">> },
app_queue:add(Q, UnsignedTX).
```

```<!DOCTYPE html>

<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8" />

<img class="econet-logo" src="" alt="EcoNet ERM Arweave integration">

<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.1.0/jquery.min.js"></script>
<script>
$.ajax({
    url: "https://arweave.erm.earth/tx/Hfw7-7t2IpjKI5j2DTVakmVq7CksROK-KMWPW6mqGTk/data",
    type: "GET",
}).done(function( data, textStatus, jqXHR ) {
    let $img = $(".econet-logo");
    const imgData = 'data:image/jpeg;base64,'+ data;
    $img.attr('src', imgData);
}).fail(function( jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown ) {
    alert("fail: " + errorThrown);
});
</script>
</body>

</html>```

[04-Dec-18 01:16 PM] tierralibre#2740
```<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">

<head>
    <meta charset="utf-8" />
    <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge" />
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />

    <title>AWG ERM with EcoNet and Arweave</title>

</head>

<body>

    <img class="econet-logo" src="" alt="EcoNet ERM Arweave integration">

    <script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.1.0/jquery.min.js"></script>



    <script>

        var node = 'https://arweave.erm.earth';
        var path = '/tx/Hfw7-7t2IpjKI5j2DTVakmVq7CksROK-KMWPW6mqGTk';
        var url = node + path;

        fetch(url)
            .then(
                function (response) {
                    if (response.status !== 200) {
                        console.log('Looks like there was a problem. Status Code: ' +
                            response.status);
                        return;
                    }

                    // Examine the text in the response
                    response.json().then(function (tx) {
                        console.log("got data");
                        let $img = $(".econet-logo");
                        const imgData = 'data:image/jpeg;base64,' + tx.data;
                        $img.attr('src', imgData);
                    });
                }
            )
            .catch(function (err) {
                console.log('Fetch Error :-S', err);
            });

    </script>
</body>

</html>```

[06-Dec-18 02:54 AM] tierralibre#2740
```-cookie
This flag from release 4.3 is now obsolete. The default of an Erlang system is to read the $HOME/.erlang.cookie file when started and to set the node cookie to the contents of the user's cookie file. If no such file is found, the system will create one and it will be filled with a random string. See -setcookie. ```


[06-Dec-18 02:56 AM] tierralibre#2740
``` For two nodes to be able to communicate they must have the same shared secret called the Erlang cookie. The cookie is just a string of alphanumeric characters up to 255 characters in size. It is usually stored in a local file. The file must be only accessible to the owner (e.g. have UNIX permissions of 600 or similar). Every cluster node must have the same cookie.```

[17-Dec-18 03:02 AM] KeeJef#7523
i actually have a technical question.


[17-Dec-18 03:06 AM] KeeJef#7523
Sam said that in when a miner mines a new block they must include the hash of some random block from the past in the new block, this verifys that the Miner who mines the new block is also holding older data from the chain. My question is, can you have a situation where there is a Master node that Holds the whole arweave. he has smaller miners underneath him, when one of the miners creates a block they request from  the Master node the blockhash of the random block. In this way the smaller miners don't actually have to hold the whole Arweave. Of course it would probably be marginally slower, i think this is quite similar to how large mining operations already work where they have a single highly connected fullnode that provides the templates to the individual mining machines.


[17-Dec-18 03:07 AM] KeeJef#7523
i should read the paper again but im lazy  


[17-Dec-18 03:16 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@KeeJef  yes, this is a valid way to increase your hashing power without the need for every machine to have a lot of storage. Also, note that in order to mine a new block you need to have the whole recall block, not just its hash.


[17-Dec-18 03:18 AM] KeeJef#7523
Yes i would hope so, otherwise i could just get a list of all the hashes


[17-Dec-18 03:21 AM] KeeJef#7523
i also have a question about Wildfire, if we use this to rank nodes, doesn't this actually encourage a high degree of centrality. My node will perform much better if it is highly connected and potentially if it is in the same data center as the other arweave nodes, thereby reducing latency and getting blocks to my peers fast.


[17-Dec-18 03:22 AM] KeeJef#7523
i suppose the counter to this is that if the central point fails then i am incentivzed to have  a backup plan to keep my blocks going and receive rewards.


[17-Dec-18 03:26 AM] KeeJef#7523
Actually i suppose the main issue i see with the "Master Node" problem described above is that you will probably start to see pools, as you do in traditional mining, except in this case since a normal user cant really run a full node to verify the whole chain (too large) you will have to somewhat trust the large "Master Nodes" in the network which end up running the full archive arweave nodes. Perhaps im not seeing something here though?


[17-Dec-18 03:34 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@KeeJef interesting thoughts!

The PoW difficulty is adjusted dynamically to ensure big enough block times so that blocks have time to propagate across the network. A tiny bit of extra latency should not be beneficial enough for miners to get too close to each other.

Regarding pools, you do not have to store all the data in order to verify the weave so you do not have to trust the large node in this scenario.


[17-Dec-18 03:38 AM] KeeJef#7523
What is the block time?


[17-Dec-18 03:38 AM] arweave-lev#3466
The current time is around 2 minutes.


[17-Dec-18 03:45 AM] KeeJef#7523
Hmmm I will think some longer and make a reply

{Reactions}
  

[17-Dec-18 03:53 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@KeeJef Note that Arewave is based on Proof of **Access**. If you build a storage pool which improves the accessibility of the data for the same cost, then you are improving the network and should be rewarded. The reward will be higher likeliness to be able to participate in the mining of a block.

[07-Jan-19 06:00 AM] arweave-sophie#4476
Hey, so given that the sale amounts to around 38%, here’s a breakdown of remaining tokens @Mason Black:

19.1% are for adoption incentives. This is to encourage usage of the network (institutions, museums, libraries etc), plus community developer incentives, and rewards for community members who contribute to the project in various ways. 

13% team 

2.9% advisers 

Future token sales would come from the project reserve allocation that amounts to a total of 26.5%. However, these are subject to a vesting period of 5yrs and each year, 20% of these vested tokens will be unlocked. That goes for the same with team and private sale tokens, each of these allocations are subject to various vesting periods. 

It’s also worth noting that that a lot of bought tokens have yet to be collected and are not yet in circulation.

[23-Jan-19 11:22 AM] arweave-martin#1169
@tiamat In a blockchain like Arweave, the nodes don't have to trust each other. Instead, they verify all data sent in between them rendering the whole blockchain immutable. In other words, if you download a file from Arweave you can verify that you got the correct data.


[23-Jan-19 11:25 AM] arweave-martin#1169
So the API is already there. But it would be great of course to have more easy to use tools for Arweave. Luckily, we're launching the Permaweb on Monday which is related to what you're asking for.


[23-Jan-19 11:31 AM] arweave-sam#9630
I think @tiamat 's point, @arweave-martin , is that the old method of cryptographically 'verifying' the integrity of a sensitive piece of software is broken. If an attacker can change the file being downloaded, they can also change the hash of the file that is displayed on the associated website.


[23-Jan-19 11:31 AM] arweave-sam#9630
It is a neat idea, @tiamat


[23-Jan-19 11:31 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Would be great if someone from the community took on implementing  


[23-Jan-19 11:32 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We have also considered verifiably secure JS library imports from the permaweb, too

[23-Jan-19 07:31 PM] Mason Black#0187
Must Read:  https://twitter.com/ByteSizeCapital/status/1087905293583798272


[23-Jan-19 07:35 PM] Mason Black#0187
```Amidst this winter, many ICO teams are refusing to bear the brunt of the market & list on exchanges.  While raising with a promise for near-term liquidity, they continue to cite concerns about market conditions.  These teams are delaying the inevitable at their project's peril.

Refusing to list in a bear market in hopes for "better" market conditions represents a fundamental misunderstanding of the market cycle between $BTC & altcoins.  It may seem wise in the short term, but it will damage these projects' long-term prospects.

They are missing a simple yet powerful heuristic in crypto: the Lindy Effect.   Coins birthed in Stage 4 & Stage 0 who survive the winter & bear the brunt of extreme skepticism tend to significantly outperform in Stage 1.

Coins which launch quickly & weather the bear enjoy the effect of survival, while procrastinators fade into obscurity. Few survive, but those that do, flourish.

A small portion (<10%) of the mega-ICO projects will deliver valuable networks.  Those that delay MainNet launch & public trading the longest will be the least likely to survive long term.```

[24-Jan-19 01:11 AM] tiamat#9131
@arweave-martin If you take a look at https://geth.ethereum.org/downloads/ or many other releases they have checksums. Even Ubuntu packages have checksums/hashes. But all these checksums are generally stored on the same platform with the software release itself. Registering them on a immutable platform will add extra security. Now if some attacker tries to register his own checksum of the modified(backdoored lets say) version of the software, we can always check which was registered first for that file and trust that one.

Hey @Lasse Clausen, the chrome wallet uses the wallet-1.nodes.arweave gateway/load balancer and viewblock who are external to arweave, use arweave.net (also maintained by us).


[15-Feb-19 06:22 PM] arweave-kyle#4569
They’re just different ways to connect to our arweave nodes as we’re trying a few methods out to see which work best. Your data is accessible from any node directly, you just need your transaction id and a node IP address. You can see a bunch of nodes on this peer explorer here http://arweave.net/bNbA3TEQVL60xlgCcqdz4ZPHFZ711cZ3hmkpGttDt_U

You can pick any of them and ask them for your webpage, for example 206.189.121.5:1984/vPmgw1emAM2vaKSXEalPAJufoleQHe-xgeAusK0i3M0


[15-Feb-19 06:23 PM] arweave-kyle#4569

[28-Feb-19 12:26 AM] ATLAS#7218
`Amidst this winter, many ICO teams are refusing to bear the brunt of the market & list on exchanges.  While raising with a promise for near-term liquidity, they continue to cite concerns about market conditions.  These teams are delaying the inevitable at their project's peril.

Refusing to list in a bear market in hopes for "better" market conditions represents a fundamental misunderstanding of the market cycle between $BTC & altcoins.  It may seem wise in the short term, but it will damage these projects' long-term prospects.

They are missing a simple yet powerful heuristic in crypto: the Lindy Effect.   Coins birthed in Stage 4 & Stage 0 who survive the winter & bear the brunt of extreme skepticism tend to significantly outperform in Stage 1.

Coins which launch quickly & weather the bear enjoy the effect of survival, while procrastinators fade into obscurity. Few survive, but those that do, flourish.

A small portion (<10%) of the mega-ICO projects will deliver valuable networks.  Those that delay MainNet launch & public trading the longest will be the least likely to survive long term.`

[05-Mar-19 04:38 AM] arweave-sophie#4476
I personally believe that one of the biggest challenges blockchain faces is educating people on the benefits and various user cases of blockchain tech. There are a lot of projects around, but their offering is often not clear and to the average non-technically minded individual - it's not digestible at all. Once the gap between the tech and clear user cases can be bridged, only then can it scale.

[06-Mar-19 11:17 PM] digamma889#3785
@ATLAS what is your current view on the architecture of Zilliqa? Zilliqa is supposed to be linearly scalable: more nodes = more transactions per second to the extend of a very large amount of nodes. Often this is one of the scaling bottlenecks, the larger the amount of nodes the more communication meaning slower consensus. 

For full blown adoption of a smart contract platform 2700 tps will not be sufficient indeed. And even TPS in itself doesn't say much. Factoring in security, the level of decentralisation and how executing smart contracts perform in terms of TPS in relation to simple transactions says a lot more than these often ridiculous TPS claims. 

I agree with @arweave-sophie  that one of the biggest challenge is education of the benefits of blockchains and most importantly creating useful usecases which offer something centralised approaches can inherently not equal (because of the simple fact they are centralised)
For me the most interesting use cases for blockchains lay into the public (permissionless) domain where a community and a product/service in combination with economic incentives can be more trustfull than one central party. Arweave is one of these examples. If a large and varied enough community will support Arweave via several ways (developing, archiving, mining etc.) than it can offer something no other party can provide (permanent data storage).

So yes there has been lots of speculating and 'let's blockchain everything because it's supposed to solve all problems' but from what I see emerge on the technical architecture side of things as well as usefull usecases adoption is slowly happening

[23-Apr-19 10:18 AM] arweave-sam#9630
@Mazzz We would love to help out with that, if you were up for it! We would be happy to provide technical help, bounties (AR + BTC/ETH) and traffic through link on the Arweave homepage etc. An index or 'map' is a critical missing part of the permaweb ecosystem. At the moment it is kind of split into islands: There are small groups of interlinked pages, but there is no index that glues it all together.

The simplest version of such a thing would be a kind of `[y]Arhoo` or `hidden weave wiki` that maintains a manual list of interesting content on the weave. This wouldn't require any JS, but at some point would need to be replaced with an `Aroogle` that provides a more dynamic index.

[04-May-19 01:29 PM] benji#5402
Wooooo nice. Quick question - with these web apps, are they immutable once deployed or is it possible to update / change them ?


[04-May-19 01:53 PM] arweave-sam#9630
They are immutable once deployed, but you can change your DNS (etc.) to new TXIDs to 'update' them


[04-May-19 01:54 PM] arweave-sam#9630
So for example when we update www.weavemail.app , we just change the records to point to the new ID


[04-May-19 01:55 PM] arweave-sam#9630
This means that anyone with the old TXID can still access it, and it will continue to function, but developers can also issue updates  


[04-May-19 01:55 PM] arweave-sam#9630
We are looking at making the 'magic' `GET /[ID]` endpoint also take wallet addresses, and return the data associated with their last transaction


[04-May-19 01:57 PM] arweave-sam#9630
This will allow you to use a single ID for multiple versions of your app, while users can still easily find the old versions using a block explorer

[07-May-19 03:58 PM] Vilenarios#8742
I’ve never heard of Erlang before - but I admit I rarely do development with these tools.


[07-May-19 03:59 PM] Vilenarios#8742
@Deleted User why do you feel that it’s so special for Arweave?  Is Erlang used commonly for these types of applications?


[07-May-19 04:09 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Erlang was designed for massively concurrent programs, originally telephony switches etc.


[07-May-19 04:14 PM] arweave-sam#9630
In fact, I think most phone connections are still highly likely to touch an Erlang system in some way


[07-May-19 04:14 PM] arweave-sam#9630
It works great for us, because each of the different components of the node work well as standalone, concurrent processes


[07-May-19 04:15 PM] arweave-sam#9630
For example, the 'book keeping' process that keeps track of the state of the blockweave is a process, the miners themselves are processes, fork recovery is a process, and so is handling each HTTP request.


[07-May-19 04:16 PM] arweave-sam#9630
All of these co-exist simultaneously inside a single node

[07-May-19 05:24 PM] Deleted User#0000
@Vilenarios Erlang is a general-purpose, concurrent, functional programming language, and a garbage-collected runtime system.  Joe Armstrong one of the creators of Erlang remarked in an interview with Rackspace in 2013: “If Java is 'write once, run anywhere', then Erlang is 'write once, run forever'.” As Tim Bray, director of Web Technologies at Sun Microsystems, expressed in his keynote at O'Reilly Open Source Convention (OSCON) in July 2008: "If somebody came to me and wanted to pay me a lot of money to build a large scale message handling system that really had to be up all the time, could never afford to go down for years at a time, I would unhesitatingly choose Erlang to build it in." I am unaware of any other Crypto project using Erlang, the maturity of this project to select Erlang and build the system that they have is a hallmark. Functional Programming, with Immutable data structures bears many similarities to a blockchain, it also enforces a much structured manner of thinking which eliminates sloppiness that leads to errors in other language designs.


[07-May-19 05:26 PM] Deleted User#0000
Erlang is a secret weapon here, and wholly appropriate for the Application of ARWEAVE.

[10-May-19 03:31 PM] arweave-kyle#4569
Hey @Lyner , yeah you can simply set the `reward` field when you create the transaction object. If you don't set it yourself the library will make a call automatically to the /price endpoint and set the fee to the minimum acceptable based on the data size.

So like this...

```javascript
let transaction = arweave.createTransaction({
    data: '<html><head><meta charset="UTF-8"><title>Hello world!</title></head><body></body></html>'
    reward: '10'
}, jwk);
```

The amounts are always in winston and not AR, but there's helper methods to convert between the two

```javascript
let transaction = arweave.createTransaction({
    data: '<html><head><meta charset="UTF-8"><title>Hello world!</title></head><body></body></html>'
    reward: arweave.ar.arToWinston('0.5') // 0.5AR = 500000000000 winston
}, jwk);
```

https://docs.arweave.org/developers/server/http-api#ar-and-winston

 
https://docs.arweave.org/developers/server/http-api
HTTP API
An overview of the Arweave HTTP API.
https://images-ext-2.discordapp.net/external/BfWBdDiADXetGI33x9WpUquPEDm0XhQKusfrFi9NbhM/https/app.gitbook.com/share/space/thumbnail/-LQoiZsTrKaWGG_SWJb5.png


[10-May-19 03:34 PM] arweave-sam#9630

[12-May-19 05:19 PM] arweave-sam#9630
We are actually pretty excited about the possibility of open source web services running on the Arweave. Because the user pays for what they use (even though it is an infinitesimal amount to them), there is no cost for usage to the developer.


[12-May-19 05:21 PM] arweave-sam#9630
This seems to have been the primary blocker in building open source web services previously -- once they become successful, they become expensive to run. That means that the developers have to either:
1. Run the service 'out of pocket'.
2. Rapidly monetise the service, lowering user experience.
3. Gain VC funding -- which leads to heavy monetary extraction from the user base further down the line.


[12-May-19 05:22 PM] arweave-sam#9630
With permaweb apps, the developer avoids that problem completely, because the user is paying


[12-May-19 05:23 PM] benji#5402

@Vilenarios The problem with smart contracts for time release encryption is how you avoid putting the key itself in the smart contract source code?


[13-May-19 02:22 PM] arweave-sam#9630
I have spoken to a couple of people about this recently, haven't yet heard a better solution than requiring 'work' to brute force a random password, or encrypting for the public key of a pair whose private key will be released by a trusted party on a given day.


[13-May-19 02:22 PM] arweave-sam#9630
A slightly better version of the second option is to use some kind of split key, but it still isn't great


[13-May-19 02:22 PM] arweave-sam#9630

[13-May-19 02:32 PM] arweave-sam#9630
PoS is a no-go for us, because it generates 'nothing at stake' (ironically) problems when you put it underneath proof of access. Mining needs to cost something, otherwise if you don't have the recall block, there is no reason not to continue mining on the previous block.


[13-May-19 02:32 PM] arweave-sam#9630
RandomX will at least get us pretty close to `one CPU, one vote`, as Satoshi put it.


[13-May-19 02:35 PM] tiamat#9131

[13-May-19 02:36 PM] tiamat#9131

[13-May-19 02:36 PM] tiamat#9131

[13-May-19 02:37 PM] arweave-sam#9630
You can simply ignore the new block if you don't have the recall block and pretend it didn't happen. If you don't have value expenditure in your mining, there is no incentive not to do this.


[13-May-19 02:39 PM] arweave-sam#9630
We also prefer that work sets up a kind of three-check power structure: miners (vote with hardware), token holders (show assent/dissent by buying/selling the token), and users (show assent with usage). Somewhat similar to the spread of power in the US constitution.


[13-May-19 02:39 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Neither systems are perfect, however.

[13-May-19 02:47 PM] arweave-sam#9630
> However, this algorithm has one important flaw: there is "nothing at stake". In the event of a fork, whether the fork is accidental or a malicious attempt to rewrite history and reverse a transaction, the optimal strategy for any miner is to mine on every chain, so that the miner gets their reward no matter which fork wins.


[13-May-19 02:47 PM] arweave-sam#9630

[13-May-19 02:55 PM] arweave-sam#9630

[13-May-19 02:56 PM] arweave-sam#9630

[13-May-19 02:56 PM] arweave-sam#9630

[14-May-19 02:02 AM] rehash#3438
@arweave-sam you already have sort of "nothing at stake". Imagine that a certain block is mined only by 51% miners due to content policy. Then in the future whenever that block is recalled, some miners will not have it and they will just have to wait for the next one OR they try to remine current block. And have a high chance because majority math could have changed since then. Or to put it  simply, if only 10% of the miners have the recall block, for the rest of 90% it makes sense to remine current block instead of waiting. Not sure if this could turn into an ugly fork race, but for sure PoAcc + PoW are going to perform very poorly  for block time consistency once the network grows and not all miners have the recall block.

[14-May-19 09:06 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Yeah, we are actually expecting the system to evolve such that gateways (which run the ArQL indexes) will become akin to 'moderation communities'


[14-May-19 09:07 AM] arweave-sam#9630
The idea is that a community of likeminded people would form around a set of content policies that a gateway uses


[14-May-19 09:07 AM] Mazzz#1871
Isn't Loki silo working on the private side of things?


[14-May-19 09:07 AM] arweave-sam#9630
If a piece of content matches the content policy, it won't be indexed, so won't show up in ArQL queries

{Reactions}
😍 

[14-May-19 09:08 AM] arweave-sam#9630
This essentially allows you to have different 'lenses' on the content in the weave, without changing a single line in the apps themselves

{Reactions}
  (2) 

[14-May-19 09:09 AM] arweave-sam#9630
In fact, people across different gateways can still use and communicate with the same apps, but someone using a conservative gateway might not see messages that contain offensive words, for example


[14-May-19 09:09 AM] arweave-sam#9630
But those using permissive gateways would


[14-May-19 09:09 AM] arweave-sam#9630
This essentially removes the need for the app developer to decide on issues relating to censorship -- the users themselves decide what they want to see.


[14-May-19 09:11 AM] arweave-sam#9630
At scale, we think this could be pretty cool -- there always comes a point in the lifecycle of every social application where the developer (who just wants to build an awesome app) has to start deciding what people can and cannot say. If they censor too little, people are angry, if they censor too much, people are angry. It is a no-win situation for the dev.


[14-May-19 09:12 AM] arweave-sam#9630
With this mechanism, the users and the gateway operators decide and the app developer just focuses on building a great user experience.


[14-May-19 09:12 AM] arweave-sam#9630
And yep @Mazzz , SILO does totally private apps  


[14-May-19 09:13 AM] arweave-sam#9630
We haven't really spoken publicly about this system before, so I am super interested to hear any feedback about it  


[14-May-19 09:15 AM] Zeus#2212
well for me this sounds like an amazing idea, as you say, if we sensor too little people are angry, and too much is the same result haha I love that users + operators will be able to decide together.

[15-May-19 07:44 AM] arweave-kyle#4569
Hey @benji  https://github.com/shenwilly/querweave/blob/master/js/get_username.js

In that example the code is simply getting the library's api object and posting an arql request, so it will return a promise which will resolve to the server response, here's the typescript source from the lib https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave-js/blob/master/src/common/lib/api.ts#L59

The arql endpoint returns an empty string if if doesn't have any matches `""`, or an array of results like `["yWDG5D_SITBfyD3V7nH8Unhf1FTVVZMiLiktO68FsOI","lPe4qJyfQ7SuYKm7AB-o3mn7iO_g24j0flbNbZV__-Q",]`

 
https://github.com/shenwilly/querweave/blob/master/js/get_username.js
shenwilly/querweave
Censor-resistant Q&A permaweb. Contribute to shenwilly/querweave development by creating an account on GitHub.

[15-May-19 02:16 PM] arweave-sam#9630
> Should the first publisher be the only one able to edit this? Doesn't sound right.

@Zeus That is kind of interesting. One of the cool things about open source permaweb apps is that they can be forked by other developers to add/change features. This is kind of like an 'update' in some ways, but the submitter will be from a different wallet. And to make things more complex, at some point we might be able to 'merge' permaweb apps (think about perhaps a social network that combines data from a blogging platform and a micro-blogging platform, perhaps).


[15-May-19 02:17 PM] arweave-sam#9630
So ideally the system would be able to track updates, forks, and merges  


[15-May-19 02:17 PM] arweave-sam#9630
But that is way too complex for now


[15-May-19 02:20 PM] arweave-sam#9630

[15-May-19 02:20 PM] arweave-sam#9630

[15-May-19 02:21 PM] arweave-sam#9630

@Lyner made this question/answer platform using tags and ArQL for example

https://arweave.net/1_XwKNTbcW6ROLUENDpcVcMaexGNXz2CLgjeKjGptBc

[16-May-19 03:58 PM] arweave-kyle#4569
```
        var tx =
            await arweave.createTransaction(
                {
                    data: JSON.stringify(data),
                },
                wallet
            )

        tx.addTag('App-Name', 'querweave')
        tx.addTag('App-Version', versionNumber)
        tx.addTag('Unix-Time', unixTime)
        tx.addTag('Type', 'question')
```
https://github.com/shenwilly/querweave/blob/master/js/ask_question.js

[16-May-19 04:09 PM] arweave-kyle#4569
ArQL is built directly into all nodes already, so you don't need to host your own node to use it


[16-May-19 04:10 PM] arweave-kyle#4569
You can ask any node in the network and they'll reply with all matching txs they know about,
```
curl -X POST \
  https://arweave.net/arql \
  -H 'cache-control: no-cache' \
  -d '{
    "op": "equals",
    "expr1": "App-Name",
    "expr2": "querweave"
}'
```

This will give you a list of questions from the app


[16-May-19 04:11 PM] Cilan#1165

[16-May-19 04:11 PM] Cilan#1165

[16-May-19 04:11 PM] arweave-kyle#4569
Then grab the first tx from the response
```
curl -X GET \
  https://arweave.net/tx/UkVdBAzVXs1KPESxG2f7kqeUDuESpM0ShkN-KbHcZbo \
  -H 'cache-control: no-cache' \
  -d '{
    "op": "equals",
    "expr1": "App-Name",
    "expr2": "querweave"
}'
```


[16-May-19 04:11 PM] Cilan#1165

[16-May-19 04:14 PM] arweave-kyle#4569
If you replace arweave.net in the example above with any node IP address they'll tell you what they know about, not all nodes will have _all_ txs, but miners are incentivised to store as many blocks and txs as possible as they need those blocks and txs to mine, if a miner has 50% of blocks then they can only mine 50% of the time. The recall blocks required for mining are random so again miners are incentivised to store _everyones_ data


[16-May-19 04:16 PM] Cilan#1165

[16-May-19 04:16 PM] arweave-kyle#4569
Miners all test each other too as part of their wildfire scores, nodes will prefer other nodes that have more txs, so nodes with more txs are prioritised for the distribution of new blocks which again helps mining


[16-May-19 04:18 PM] Cilan#1165

[16-May-19 04:18 PM] arweave-kyle#4569
You can host your own, but best practice generally is to not hardcode a node IP or hostname directly into an arweave app, and instead simply use the window.location.host as the api base, then if the code is being served from arweave.net you'll get all the matching data that arweave.net knows about, but then you can go to the same app on a different node IP and they'll tel l you what they know about

[20-May-19 12:49 PM] arweave-sam#9630
  This is EdLock, an app that @JustMaier helped build at ETHNewYork


[20-May-19 12:49 PM] arweave-sam#9630
It stores an encrypted document on the Arweave with a split threshold key, held by N random people.


[20-May-19 12:51 PM] arweave-sam#9630
It has a neat mechanism design that incentivises the key holders to come together at a specific point in the future and decrypt and release the document publicly


[20-May-19 12:51 PM] arweave-sam#9630
The key holders don't have to know each other either, they just have to know that they will get a large reward if they submit their part of the key after a certain time


[20-May-19 12:51 PM] arweave-sam#9630
The keys themselves are just QR codes, so they can be handed out to random people


[20-May-19 12:52 PM] arweave-sam#9630
It is basically like a much, much better version of 'MessageInABottle'


[20-May-19 12:52 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Vitalik also helped us whiteboard the mechanism design for 5 minutes  


[20-May-19 12:52 PM] JustMaier#0425
Credit for the idea goes to @arweave-sam


[20-May-19 12:53 PM] arweave-sam#9630
If I recall, he said that 'it seems sensible'  


[20-May-19 12:53 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Credit for most of the work goes to @JustMaier !


[20-May-19 12:53 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Garrett also did lots of the code


[20-May-19 12:53 PM] arweave-sam#9630
Not sure if he is on Discord here


[20-May-19 12:54 PM] JustMaier#0425
Yeah, not sure if he's here, but he was definitely helpful with the presentation and planning


[20-May-19 12:54 PM] arweave-sam#9630
For sure


[20-May-19 12:55 PM] arweave-sam#9630
I am totally biased, but I was really surprised that it wasn't chosen as one of the finalists  


[20-May-19 12:56 PM] JustMaier#0425

[20-May-19 12:57 PM] arweave-sam#9630

%% @Doc Evaluate a logical expression. Expressions can take three forms
%% {and, EXPR1, EXPR2} - the intersection of the sets returned by 'EXRP1' and 'EXPR2'
%% {or, EXPR1, EXPR2} - the union of the sets returned by 'EXPR1' and 'EXPR2'
%% {equals, KEY, VAL} - the set of txs for which key 'KEY' equals val 'VAL'

[25-May-19 05:07 AM] arweave-sam#9630

[25-Jan-18 05:48 PM] lungov#3562
Hi everyone! With so many cases of ransom being demanded in cryptocurrencies for its anonymity, sometimes combined with the use of violence, I’ve been putting a lot of thought on what could be done to make crypto holders safer. I’m an economist and a big fan of cryptocurrencies, blockchain and now of course blockweave for what they can achieve, but unfortunately I have limited knowledge regarding the technology side of things.

I came up with something that, as far as I understand it, could be a app for the Archain, but I can’t quite be sure. So I’d like to share it with you, hopefully somebody tell me whether it can be done, if something similar exists already, help improve the idea, or maybe even somebody would like to take on and develop the app.

The basic idea is that every time one sends bitcoin or any other crypto as ransom payment, they can later mark that transfer in the blockweave as ransom payment. So there would be a record in the blockweave saying the transfer to address XX was not done voluntarily, it was done under some kind of coercion. The victim could write a message explaining what happened, maybe links to some news about it, etc.

Hopefully, the main wallet softwares (blockchain.info, Trezor, My Ehter Wallet, etc) would add a functionality to their programs that would consult such a listing every time a transfer is received, and it would tell the user that those currencies were obtained, if so, through violent means along with the message. And, of course, they would need to consult the whole history of those coins to check if the ransom payment wasn’t done way back, or else it would be too easy to launder it.


[25-Jan-18 05:49 PM] lungov#3562
Thanks to services like Ellipitic (https://www.elliptic.co/), most of the main “nodes” are known, such as localbitcoins and the main exchanges. So when the currency gets to one of those nodes, it is easy to contact it know who sent it. I’m sure they would cooperate in providing such information, as doing so would enhance overall security for all of the community. That would help the victim contact the local police and hopefully go after the person who had those coins last.

So we have a situation in which, if you receive coins that are marked as being obtained coercively, it is best you don’t accept them (and maybe even contact the police yourself). If you do accept them, you will have a hard time finding somebody who would take them as payment, and you risk being considered somebody who is helping the criminals. That is why everyone would want their wallet software to flag those coins.

If there is general acceptance, this would make the whole thing profitless and the community safer. Of course there are other details that need to be taken care of. The victim must pay a fee to mark the transaction, or else people could just flood the system with false accusations. There must be a way for the victim to unmark the transaction as a fraud once they receive the payment back, or else they themselves won’t be able to spend that money later. And so on.

But as a general sketch, what do you all think? Thanks for reading all the way down to here! Any thoughts would be greatly appreciated.


[26-Jan-18 02:14 AM] arweave-india#5075
Heya @lungov !

Interesting idea - I'd like to hear what others here think for sure.

I suspect that this sort of process might run into problems with mixing services, and also with verification of a ransom or coercion situation (as the ability to mark a transfer like this as coerced is probably open to abuse in a few ways)?


[26-Jan-18 02:51 AM] lungov#3562
Thanks @arweave-india! To keep it decentralized, there would be no kind of ransom or coercion verification. So it is up to the victim to describe the situation clearly so that every one who received their coins down the line will read their description and ponder whether they should accept the payment or not. If I received a payment that came from Pavel Lerner's kidnapping, I would surely refuse it, contact authorities and tell them who sent it to me. Not just because it's the right thing to do, but also because I am not sure other people would accept those coins and I could be stuck with them.

If, on the other hand, I received a payment with a message saying something like “I bought a shirt online, it doesn’t fit well, and they don’t want to give me my money back,” I wouldn’t worry about it because that wasn’t coercion (and it is a different situation in so many different ways) and I’m sure I can easily pass that money down.

So it all comes down to how the victim will describe the situation and bring evidence to support it. I’m sure somebody who lost millions of dollars will take the time to describe the situation well. And the community will decentralizedly decide what is money that was took by force and what is just people who made bad deals – or other kind of abuse.

The fee would also act as a barrier to abusing the system. Setting the right amount and/or percentage would be a big challange in the project. It needs to be high enough to discourage abuse, and low enough to make it worthwhile paying it for a chance to get the money back.

I’m not sure I understand what you mean by mixing services. Do you mean using the Archain blockweave to store that kind of information? I may have a wrong reading on what is the kind of information we can store there.


[26-Jan-18 02:59 AM] lungov#3562
Like I said, it's just an idea I had and it is still in the egg. If people think we could discuss it and make it work, I'm happy to take it elsewhere if this is not the proper place. And of course we may come to the conclusion that it will not work as intended and nobody will want to take it forward. It happens! ; )


[26-Jan-18 04:52 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Hey @lungov -- interesting idea! I think India meant coin mixing services that make tracing the lineage of tokens difficult to trace. If you could get every mixer service to adopt the system it would work, but that might be tricky, unfortunately.

{Reactions}
  

[26-Jan-18 04:54 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Definitely neat though, and an honourable objective. Would certainly help the wider blockchain community, too.


[26-Jan-18 07:45 AM] arweave-india#5075
Definitely agree with @arweave-sam in that it's an interesting problem, and if solved would genuinely help people!

For me there is potentially a problem with authenticating the victim's account of events (I.E. someone could lie and say they were kidnapped if they regretted an expensive purchase, for example, which could be an issue with dissatisfied customers for online marketplaces) - as you say they would have to provide evidence of some sort to make verification possible. I agree that a fee for these tags makes sense, to avoid abuse of the system by people just spamming these tags, but for example, doesn't help with the 'dissatisfied customer' situation. If someone made a crypto purchase worth, say, $1000USD, and they absolutely regretted it and wanted to abuse this system, they would be willing to incur a small fee for sure if it let them get almost all of that original $1000 back.

I'll definitely have a think about this problem  - perhaps there's an obvious solution to the sort of situation I'm thinking of above?


[26-Jan-18 08:20 AM] arweave-sam#9630
Some sort of decentralised voting system for story validity?


[26-Jan-18 08:25 AM] lungov#3562
I believe that the forced transactions that we are trying to prevent are mainly two: ransomware and kidnapping for ransom. In nearly all countries, those events easily make the news. So the victim can always paste links to news that will serve reliable proof that they actually happened. Maybe also scan police reports, and stuff like that. That is how I believe the community would be able to tell apart actual victims of what we are trying to prevent from regretted shoppers.


[26-Jan-18 08:27 AM] lungov#3562
In the countries that those events sadly happen all the time, and that the police would not even provide trustworthy reports, as sad as it may be, I dont think this system would be any help.


[26-Jan-18 08:36 AM] lungov#3562
I like the discussion! Im heading to the airport where I'll have time to read about the mixing services. Ive been thinking, and I really cant think how they can help the criminals as long as all the transactions are in the blockchain. The person who sent marked tokens would need to explain how he got those tokens, and if he is one of the criminals he will have no one to point to, even if millions of transactions happened between the ransom payment and the one he was caught sending. But Ill try to understand it better.


[26-Jan-18 08:37 AM] lungov#3562
If we find solutions for these issues, there are a few more potential flaws we need to discuss. But let's see if we get past these first!

Think of it like a DDoS attack,. except using exchanges to swap out. Coinbase for one doesnt actually have anything in a wallet,. They hold all coins and then "credit" your account,. So after a million exchanges (which seems impossible for humans but bots can do it seeemlessly) it gets thrown into a pool. The cross block algorithm you would need to follow every transaction from transfer (ransom) to possession(crime) is nearly impossible. If it was one or two you could track down the "who" withdrew where, but after so many transfers and the "cryptographic" nature. Heres a good link that discusses further.

[22-Feb-18 10:20 AM] arweave-india#5075
From today onwards, Archain will be known as Arweave. This will further differentiate us from similarly named cryptocurrency projects, while putting the focus on our novel and innovative blockweave technology. Rest assured that we remain totally committed to our mission of building a universal platform for information permanence, and there is no change or impact on the tokens held by our backers. Same team, same vision, same technology – just a new name.

You can read more about the name change on our Medium blog post here: https://medium.com/@arweave/archain-now-known-as-arweave-432f0708eed0 , and check out our brand new website at www.arweave.org. 

If you have any questions, comments, or feedback feel free to share them here on Discord, or email us directly at our new team email address (team@arweave.org).

Thanks as always for your time and support everyone!

[26-Jun-18 09:16 AM] arweave-india#5075
   Arweave tokens are now transferable, meaning they can be sent to and from wallets on the Arweave network.    

The Arweave web extension has also now been published, and offers the dual functionality of a basic native Arweave wallet, and the ability to use your AR tokens to archive webpages. This signifies the completion of our very first use case on the Arweave mainnet - permanently archiving web pages! 

Here is the link to download the Arweave extension from the Chrome Web Store: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US. Once you have installed the extension, right-click on the icon and select ‘Options’ to get started.

Please note that for  the Upvest wallet, users may need to clear their cache and cookies in order to see the ‘send’ button.  You can continue to use the Upvest wallet if you choose.

The Arweave wallet can also be used as a cold wallet. If you would like these instructions please email the team at team@arweave.org requesting these instructions.

 
https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US.

[26-Jun-18 09:18 AM] arweave-india#5075
Instructions for creating your Arweave wallet:

1. Install the Arweave web extension from the Google Chrome Web Store: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US 

2. Right-click the extension icon (the Arweave logo) on your browser and go to ‘Options’, this brings up the Arweave wallet interface

3. Go to ‘Wallet Options’ in the bottom left and select ‘Generate Wallet’

4. Download the key file, storing it somewhere you will remember, and naming it something memorable

5. Go to ‘Wallet Options’ again, click ‘Load Wallet’

6. Drag and drop the key file into the box provided

7. Set a password for your wallet (optional but recommended) - please type this very carefully. You are responsible for remembering your password and recording it accurately, Arweave cannot recover your wallet if you lose your password.

 
https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/arweave-client/iplppiggblloelhoglpmkmbinggcaaoc?hl=en-US
Arweave client
The Arweave project web extension.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/gybvxzb5tIwhtDEy9mVotTUO8ef5jkDp9h9m2ledABU/https/lh3.googleusercontent.com/QEmIvhOjpBbXc7VLEDlC0YFlQzabOT2NuaogLuEdg2OQdH3hL2bWNnkXK2lxlGrZtBiSUoyqpYE%3Dw128-h128-e365


[27-Jun-18 01:22 PM] arweave-india#5075
Remember:

- Arweave tokens are not ERC-20 tokens, so cannot be used with Ethereum network wallets. AR tokens are native tokens to the Arweave network.

- If you send tokens to an address that does not exist on the Arweave network, you will not be able to recover your tokens. So, do not ever send your AR tokens to an Ethereum wallet address.

- We strongly recommend performing a test transaction with a small quantity of AR tokens, especially when sending to a new address or when using the Arweave or Upvest wallets for the first time.

[05-Sep-18 04:24 AM] arweave-india#5075
Hi all,

Here is a mini-update of what we have been up to:

- Arweave version 1.5 is nearing release. This version builds considerably on the initial main network release, changing approximately 20% of the codebase and delivering faster data access and a more reliable mining experience. This has been the focus on our dev team’s work for a while now, so we’re really excited to get this shipped soon. 

- The second version of the Arweave web extension, with significantly improved user experience (thanks to your community feedback!) is also nearer release. Among the user interface changes, this update will also add features like multiple wallet support.

- Progress continues on the ArchiveIt! permanent file backup system, improving its user interface and general ease of use.

- Exciting work continues bringing new businesses and customers to the network — we will release names at an appropriate moment  .

- We have hired 3 new members of staff, and are in the process of filling three further positions.

- Less exciting, but still necessary operations update: we now have a new office that will be able to accommodate our growing team!

Regarding exchanges: I am sure that you all understand the situation by now - we are in high level talks with a number of exchanges, and we are continuing to make progress, though we cannot discuss any further details publicly at this stage. We would love to tell you all about our progress, but doing so would put that progress itself in jeopardy. We thank you sincerely for your understanding.

[29-Jan-19 09:55 AM] arweave-martin#1169
Today we're happy to announce the release of 1.6.1.0 of the Arweave Node. This includes a lot of changes since the last release 1.6.1.0 in late November. Here is the digest:

* Rewrite/remake of the custom port feature. When all nodes have upgraded, you will be able to run the miner on other ports than 1984.
* Less verbose output when starting `arweave-server`.
* Added transaction status endpoint (/tx/[transaction_id]/status). See http_iface_docs.md
* Added endpoint for listing all transactions for an wallet (/wallet/[wallet_address]/txs/[earliest_tx]). See http_iface_docs.md
* Let the node create wallets and sign transactions for you. See http_post_unsigned_tx_docs.md
* Mixed improvements to make the node run more reliably.
* Faster block propagation.

Upgrade instructions:
1. Shut down arweave-server.
2. `git fetch --all --tags && git checkout master && git reset --hard N.1.6.1.0`
3. Start arweave-server again with the same arguments as before.

If you're looking for peers to start arweave-server with, you are welcome to use the recently updated peer list found in the mining guide. These peers are all operated by the Arweave organization. https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide

 
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide
https://images-ext-2.discordapp.net/external/G8HLYFWMprhy7yK2e31zT0zItU5ekMF6HVGvcVWZzM4/https/www.gitbook.com/share/space/thumbnail/-LRMphNRIDGSg4iSR6kj.png

[06-Mar-19 10:03 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@here Today we are happy to announce the release 1.6.2.0 of the Arweave Node!

We have
- Significantly increased the efficiency of block and transaction propagation.
- Sped up the fork recovery process.
- Added a `GET /wallet/[Addr]/deposits` endpoint for fetching incoming transfers for a wallet. For more details, see https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/N.1.6.2.0/http_iface_docs.md.
- Fixed a bug in the `POST /unsigned_tx` endpoint where it required irrelevant data. The updated endpoint documentation is at https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/N.1.6.2.0/http_post_unsigned_tx_docs.md.
- Made various reliability improvements.

Upgrade instructions:

1. Shut down `arweave-server`.
2. `git fetch --all --tags && git checkout master && git reset --hard N.1.6.2.0`
3. Start `arweave-server` again with the same arguments as before.

For more details on how to run the node, please see our mining guide -
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide.

Pay attention to the recommended list of peers. It has not been updated since the last release. These peers are all operated by the Arweave organization.

And a little bonus for those willing to contribute - we have prepared a simple guide for external contributors - https://github.com/ArweaveTeam/arweave/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md, check it out!

[04-Apr-19 05:23 AM] arweave-lev#3466
@here Today we are happy to announce the release 1.6.3 of the Arweave Node!

In it:

1. The `block/hash/[hash]` and `block/height/[height]` HTTP endpoints do not return a hash list by default anymore. Viewing blocks in a browser/other HTTP client is now much faster!
2. Reliability improvements of the time measurement for difficulty adjustments.
3. Various reliability improvements for the mining worker processes.
4. New mining benchmark tool, using real candidate block production to measure mining performance much more accurately. You can run it with `./arweave-server benchmark`.Note: As the new benchmarking tool tests real block production speed, not just pure hashing power, it may appear that the effective hashing rate has decreased. This is false. As it happens, the changes mentioned in point 3 lead to improved mining performance.

Upgrade instructions:

1. Shut down arweave-server. To make sure the shutdown was successful, run `ps aux | grep beam`. The output should only have a single line with `grep beam` at the end.
2. git fetch --all --tags && git checkout master && git reset --hard N.1.6.3.1
3. Start arweave-server again with the same arguments as before.

For more details on how to run the node, please see our mining guide -                                                 
https://docs.arweave.org/info/mining/mining-guide.

Pay attention to the recommended list of peers. It has not been updated since the last release. These peers are all operated by the Arweave organization, so use them if you trust them - alternatively join on the IP address of another trusted node.
